1. General Provisions This standard applies to agricultural check dams with a height of 15m or more, and auxiliary facilities or structures that are integrated with the dam and perform its functions. 1.2 Reference Standards. No content. 1.3 Definitions. None. 1.4 Benchmarks and Leveling Points (1) The contractor shall inspect the benchmarks and leveling points before the commencement of construction and submit the results to the construction supervisor (or supervisor). (2) The contractor shall properly maintain the benchmarks and leveling points designated by the construction supervisor (or supervisor) during the construction period and hand them over to the construction supervisor (or supervisor) upon completion of the construction. 1.5 Record Keeping (1) The contractor shall submit the documents specified in the construction contract documents, in the forms designated by the client or ordering entity, by the deadlines specified. (2) The contractor shall submit the following reports within the specified deadlines, in accordance with the forms designated and as directed by the site supervisor (or superintendent). ① Progress reports (daily/monthly) ② Payment item receipt status report ③ Construction materials inventory report ④ Safety and sanitation measures report ⑤ Construction equipment status report ⑥ Personnel deployment status report ⑦ As-built drawings ⑧ Other reports required by the site supervisor (or superintendent). (3) The contractor shall take color photographs of the construction work and submit a photo album summarizing the contents. (4) The contractor shall prepare and maintain work logs, payment material receiving and shipping records, and other books necessary for contract fulfillment, and shall present them to the site supervisor (or superintendent) whenever requested. 1.6 Testing and Inspection (1) The contractor shall establish and operate a testing laboratory for quality control of materials, soil, and concrete related to the construction work. The laboratory shall include not only the necessary testing equipment but also utilities, electricity, consumable supplies, reagents, and other items required for testing. (2) The contractor shall also perform separate tests as requested or directed by the superintendent (or supervisor) for construction management. (3) All quality control tests shall be performed in accordance with KS standards, testing regulations, and specifications, and the test results shall be submitted after testing. (4) The superintendent (or supervisor) may direct testing directly at the manufacturing plant or on-site if deemed necessary before the delivery of materials to the site. Alternatively, if approved by the superintendent (or supervisor), test reports conducted by the manufacturer or a recognized testing laboratory may be submitted. 1.7 Construction Management Tests (1) For each layer of earth embankment construction, three random samples shall be taken, and the moisture content and dry density shall be measured based on the observed conditions. If the construction condition is deemed incomplete, the necessary number of samples shall be taken. Furthermore, as needed, measurements of pore water pressure within the dam and foundation ground, shear and permeability tests of the earth embankment, etc., shall be performed and compared with regular construction management tests. (2) For dams constructed on weak ground, the relationship between the construction speed of the earth embankment and the dissipation of pore water pressure or the increase in ground strength shall be adjusted. (3) The dry density shall be within the allowable moisture content and above the standard specified value. (4) The earthwork test includes the field optimum moisture content of impermeable and permeable materials, selection of appropriate compaction equipment, number of compaction passes, proof rolling thickness, drying and watering methods for impermeable materials, and consultation with the construction supervisor (or superintendent) if necessary for storage methods. (5) When materials or compaction equipment are changed, a trial earthwork test must be performed to determine the proof rolling thickness, number of compaction passes, and optimum moisture content. The results shall then be submitted to the construction supervisor (or superintendent) for approval before implementation. (6) The frequency and timing of on-site quality control tests shall be in accordance with the construction specifications. (7) The trial earthwork test shall be performed on both permeable and impermeable materials with 3 types of proof rolling thickness and 3 types of compaction passes, for a total of 9 tests. 2. Materials 2.1 General Provisions (1) Soil for festivals should be assessed from various angles, including permeability and strength, but above all, it should have an ideal gradation curve. (2) Transition materials installed between the impermeable and permeable sections should use semi-permeable materials to prevent accidents caused by sudden changes in material. (3) Rock materials should be sound, have few cracks, and possess high durability against water and weathering. Specific gravity. 2.6 or greater, compressive strength of 70MPa (700kgf/cm2) or greater, durability It shall be 0.015% or less. (4) Random materials that may deteriorate due to future weathering shall not be used in critical parts of the dam. (5) For large dams, a trial embankment shall be performed at the start of construction. (6) Filter materials installed between two materials with significantly different grain sizes shall prevent the leakage of fine particles and allow seepage water to pass safely. (7) Testing of backfill materials shall be performed on the items specified in the construction specifications, and the results shall be submitted to the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor) for approval. The testing shall be performed immediately when requested by the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor). (8) Except as provided in this section, it shall comply with the provisions of "Chapter 2 Materials." 2.2 Impermeable Zone (1) The permeability coefficient of the impermeable zone shall be 1×10-5mm/sec or less. (2) Impermeable materials shall be non-permeable materials with good gradation of clay, sand, and gravel, free from plant roots and harmful large stones, and shall be approved by the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (3) Watering or drying to secure the optimum moisture content shall be performed in principle at the borrow pit, and the method shall be coordinated with the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (4) The foundation of the impermeable zone shall preferably be bedrock with as much watertightness as possible; otherwise, appropriate measures shall be taken to ensure sufficient waterproofing and stability against settlement. The foundation shall be excavated to eliminate extreme irregularities and protrusions, and appropriate treatment shall be applied to fractured and loosened layers. 2.3 Filter (1) Filter material shall have greater permeability than the material being protected by the filter, and generally should satisfy the following conditions. ① ② (2) The gradation curve of the filter material should be nearly parallel to the gradation curve of the material being protected. (3) When the material being protected by the filter contains aggregate, the above a and b clauses shall apply to the portion of that material that is 25㎜ or less. (4) The filter material shall be non-adhesive. It is generally desirable to keep the fine content of 0.074㎜ or less at 5% or less (5). Filter materials should have a permeability 10 to 100 times greater than that of the material being protected (6). Since naturally occurring materials rarely meet the aforementioned particle size requirements, they are often artificially manufactured using the following methods: ① Screening washed or crushed materials using a method similar to that used for concrete aggregate production; ② Mixing natural and artificial materials; ③ Utilizing geotextiles. 2.4 Aggregate (1) The material for aggregate shall be of such quality as to have high density, hardness, and resistance to abrasion, and shall not be susceptible to disintegration by water or frost. (2) The aggregate material shall be a well-graded, porous material with a less than 3% passing of the 200 sieve. The rock material for slope protection work 2.5 shall be a durable material that is not weathered and has sufficient individual weight to prevent displacement by rolling. The material, individual weight, and gradation shall be approved by the construction supervisor (or inspector) before use. 3. Construction 3.1 Hypothetical Cost Analysis 3. 1.1 Temporary Roads (1) The Contractor shall install the necessary roads for construction, ensuring safe passage by installing appropriate protective facilities. They shall maintain safe roadbeds and all other facilities to protect ditches and roads, ensuring ease of construction and maintenance. Subsurface investigations shall vary in method and scope depending on the purpose of the construction and the type of structure. (2) Prior to commencement of construction of the temporary road, the Contractor shall submit design drawings indicating the layout, structure, and safety facilities of the road to the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor) for approval. (3) If the temporary road crosses or overlaps existing drainage channels or other structures, it shall not reduce or damage the functionality of the existing structures. (4) If the temporary road utilizes an existing road, the Contractor shall consult with the relevant road authority in accordance with applicable laws and regulations. (5) The construction, maintenance, and restoration of the temporary road shall be the Contractor’s responsibility, and measures shall be taken to prevent complaints from landowners and others. (6) The specifications for access roads for material delivery shall be determined by sufficiently considering the size and transport frequency of the delivered materials. (7) Temporary roads connecting the main body dam site, borrow areas, and disposal areas, and access roads to the embankment slope where the extraction and dam elevations change with construction progress, shall be planned to be replaced as necessary to accommodate these changes. 3. 1.2 Temporary Works (1) The contractor shall install temporary offices, accommodations, storage facilities, workshops, toilets, etc., necessary for the construction work, so as not to hinder the construction during the construction period. (2) All maintenance of the temporary structures shall be borne by the contractor. (3) The temporary works shall prepare and submit construction drawings including location, scale, and material of the materials, and obtain the approval of the superintendent (or supervisor). 3. 1.3 Stockpile Area (1) Excavated soil generated during construction shall be stockpiled at locations approved by the construction supervisor (or engineer), maintaining an appropriate slope and ensuring proper compaction. (2) When runoff causes sediment-laden water to flow from the stockpile area, due consideration shall be given to environmental conservation and natural protection, and sufficient preventative measures shall be taken with necessary actions. 3. When using public facilities such as roads, riverbeds, and river flows, you must consult with relevant agencies and take all necessary measures before use. 3. 1.5 Diversion Structure (Water Conversion Facility) (1) Diversion Tunnel ① Construction of the diversion tunnel should be carried out during the low-flow period as much as possible. ② The waterway slope of the tunnel should be a single slope throughout the entire tunnel length. ③ The tunnel inlet should be designed to prevent scouring, erosion, and damage of the cutoff wall, and to prevent the risk of inlet closure due to collapse of the upper or upstream area. (2) Cutoff Wall ① The timing of cutoff wall construction should avoid periods when floods may occur, such as the snowmelt season, rainy season, or typhoon season. ② The height of the cutoff wall should be increased by a slight allowance over the designed maximum water depth upstream of the diversion channel. ③ When cutting the cutoff wall, the timing and construction plan should be prepared in advance and coordinated with the construction supervisor (or supervisor). ④ Cutoff walls can be constructed using a full cutoff wall or a partial cutoff wall method, selecting the most economical and safe method considering the terrain and geology at the dam site, riverbed form, flood flow size, and construction scale. a. Full Cutoff Wall: Suitable for locations with narrow base widths, regardless of the dam type. b. Partial Cutoff Wall: Suitable for locations with wide base widths and large river flow. (3) Stream-side Diversion Channel ① The bottom elevation of the diversion channel should be as low as possible, installed in a location close to the original riverbed to maximize head. ② The diversion channel is subject to dam load and water pressure, so the area around the channel should be reinforced with reinforced concrete. (4) Closure Plug of Diversion Structure ① The timing of closure of the diversion structure should be carried out during the low-flow season for its own safety. ② If there is damage to the existing water right holder downstream of the dam, the closure should be carried out during a period of residual flow downstream of the dam or during the non-irrigation period. ③ The closure of the diversion structure should be determined based on consideration of the river flow, and the construction plan, including the order of cutting, concrete placement method, and grouting process, should be prepared and approved by the construction supervisor (or supervisor) before implementation. (5) Plug ① The location of the plug should be primarily near the center line of the dam and in areas with good bedrock conditions. ② Excavation of bedrock at the plug location should be performed with caution to avoid damage to the foundation rock. ③ The layout plan for grout pipes and the concrete placement plan should be approved in advance by the construction supervisor (or supervisor). ④ Plug grouting should be performed at more than twice the working water pressure, and a sealing plate should be inserted into the contact surface with the existing concrete to prevent grout milk from leaking out. ⑤ The plug concrete is subjected to high water pressure at full supply level, causing shear stress around the plug, so the surrounding bedrock should have sufficient strength to withstand this pressure. ⑥ The length of the plug should be considered to account for the shear stress of the backfill face, activity, and fixation of the surrounding area, considering the maximum working water pressure. 0.3～ It must be at least 0.8 times. The mixing ratio of the grout milk shall be in accordance with the design details, but the final injection milk shall be mixed with a gas-generating agent such as aluminum powder to minimize shrinkage. 3.2 Foundation Excavation 3. 2.1 Dam Removal (1) The work items subject to dam removal include the dam embankments of both the temporary and main sites, and the quarry for festive materials. (2) The dam embankment should be considered as the first layer of the festive structure, and while removing unsuitable materials such as topsoil and other organic matter, it is particularly important to ensure the embankment’s adhesion is tight. (3) Removed topsoil and surface materials shall be disposed of at a location approved by the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor). 3. 2.2 Types of Excavation (1) Rock excavation refers to the removal of rock that cannot be cut without blasting or wedging, and is classified into soft rock, medium rock, and hard rock. (2) Weathered rock excavation refers to rock with low hardness or that has weathered, which can be excavated using hydraulic rippers or picks. (3) Earth excavation is divided into common soil, silty soil, colluvial clay, gravelly soil, and gravel-mixed soil, and cobble-mixed soil. 3. 2.3 Excavation for Foundation and Base Foundation

During excavation for foundation and base foundation, the following precautions shall be taken during construction.

(1) The ground shall be appropriately excavated and shaped according to the design specifications.
(2) In the case of rock excavation, as the excavation approaches the final finishing surface, the use of explosives shall be limited to prevent unnecessary shaking of the foundation, and loose rock shall be removed manually.
(3) Protruding rock encountered during excavation shall be removed, and depressions shall be backfilled and shaped with concrete according to the instructions of the construction supervisor (or superintendent) after draining any water seepage.
(4) Unless separately approved by the construction supervisor (or superintendent), any portion excavated beyond the excavation line indicated in the design specifications shall be backfilled at the contractor's expense and according to the instructions of the construction supervisor (or superintendent).
(5) Excavation and cleaning after grouting of the non-water-permeable foundation shall be performed with careful attention to prevent loosening of the solid ground.
(6) If excavated soil is to be reused as embankment material, the moisture content of the soil shall be adjusted, and the mixing of unsuitable soil shall be prevented.
(7) After excavation is completed, drainage ditches shall be installed upstream and downstream to exclude water seepage, so that clay can be installed.
(8) The foundation excavation line shall be implemented according to the topography, geology, or design specifications, and steep slopes shall be avoided.
(9) Excavation for placing cap concrete shall be constructed with the approval of the construction supervisor (or superintendent), using controlled blasting, and shall not affect the surrounding rock.
(10) Faults or fractures appearing in the foundation bedrock may cause insufficient bearing capacity, leading to differential settlement and leakage, so grouting or other special treatment shall be performed.
(11) Seepage water within the non-water-permeable trench shall be completely sealed, and the non-water-permeable layer shall be evenly applied to the foundation surface, which shall be kept in a dry state at all times.
(12) Excavation of weathered rock or soil shall be performed using earthmoving machinery at the slowest possible slope.
(13) Since the foundation portion is not visible after backfilling, a construction supervisor (or superintendent) must be present, and records, including photographs, shall be created and preserved. 3. After the foundation excavation is completed, clean it thoroughly with compressed air or water jet, and perform longitudinal and transverse surveying to create a plan view recording the location of irregularities, the type of foundation rock, the spacing, direction, and inclination of structural discontinuities. This plan view must be inspected and approved by the construction supervisor (or supervisor). 3. Adequate measures shall be taken to prevent the excavation slope from collapsing due to seepage water or other factors. Since the excavation dam is the foundation of the dam, it should be excavated using appropriate methods depending on the ground conditions, shaped according to the design drawings, and any unsuitable portions should be removed to ensure close adhesion between the dam and the dam body. 3. 3.1 Excavation Plan (1) Dam Foundation① The foundation of the dam foundation requires sufficient resistance to bearing capacity, piping, etc., and if these conditions are not met, it should be excavated in principle.② Organic materials containing roots, topsoil with low shear strength, clay or silt that cannot achieve the required shear strength, sand scattered in crevices or weak zones in bedrock that cause piping, and other similar materials that are expected to degrade in shear strength due to corrosion should all be removed. However, if removing the entire volume would be uneconomical, it may be permissible to leave them in place based on detailed bedrock investigations, soil testing, and safety assessments, provided that a separate, suitable design structure is considered.③ Generally, alluvium or weathered rock can be used as the foundation as is. Depending on the dam's size and the foundation's mechanical properties, it may be more economical to remove them, in which case shear tests and bearing capacity tests should be conducted to evaluate the removal. Continuous silty layers are frequently encountered within alluvial layers. Alluvial layers are the most difficult geological formations to investigate with borehole surveys, making it difficult to determine the shape of the silty layers.④ Therefore, in cases where detailed investigations have not been performed, trial pits, test shafts, or trench excavations should be conducted prior to earthwork construction, and safety should be confirmed based on the observed stratigraphy.⑤ If the gradation of the foundation material and the construction material is significantly different, for example, if there is a combination of silty debris, alluvium, or relatively weatherable base material with coarse gravel or rock blocks, or if there is a combination of a base material with many open cracks and fine-grained construction materials, then settlement may occur due to the loss of fine particles through the abutment joints due to rainfall or water level fluctuations.  Also, this can be a cause of soil damage on stepped, overhang, or uneven foundations. Therefore, the following measures are required for such foundations.a. If the gradation is significantly different, remove them or install a zone with appropriate gradation. The selection criteria should be determined by comparing economic feasibility and safety.b. If the excavation surface is easily weathered, treat the surface with a filter fabric or apply a thin layer of asphalt to prevent erosion even after weathering.c. For foundations with many open cracks, fill the cracks with cement paste or mortar to prevent erosion of the impermeable core and create an impermeable surface on the excavation face to reduce the amount and pressure of infiltrating water.d. While this type of crack treatment is not always highly emphasized, it should be carefully considered, especially for homogenous embankment dams, as there have been cases where fine soil has been lost through cracks due to concentrated rainfall or seepage. Excavate the site until the cracks are almost invisible, and during this process, leave the existing ground in place, and fill trenches with filters on the mountainside where cracks are present, using dimensions of 20cm x 20cm.e. It is generally not problematic to place granular materials on stepped, terraced, or uneven foundations. However, if fine-grained materials are placed, settlement is likely to occur. For foundations with these shapes, refer to the figure for bedrock. 5. Protruding portions are excavated and removed, or recessed portions are filled with concrete, mortar, etc. In the case of a soil foundation, refer to the figure. 5. When placing embankment materials as described in 2.1, excavate stepped benches of the thickness of the material being placed and backfill to ensure a good bond with the existing embankment. ⑥ If seepage water is present on the excavation surface of the dam, grouting or drainage measures should be implemented to reduce the shear strength of the embankment material or prevent the formation of piping paths. ⑦ It is generally advisable to install drains using riprap or angular rock. If the seepage quantity is large, it may be necessary to install perforated pipes. In this case, durable pipes resistant to corrosion and damage from future external forces such as earthquakes should be used. Furthermore, it is essential to encase the drains with carefully selected filter materials or geotextile filters to prevent future piping. (2) Overflow Spillway ① The overflow spillway is designed to smoothly guide the flow of water below the dam's design flood discharge to the downstream river, requiring a close combination of hydraulic, topographic, geological, and structural conditions. Therefore, changes to the excavation line after excavation begins often result in modifications to the overflow spillway, either partially or entirely. This necessitates thorough preliminary investigations. ② The following points should be considered when determining the overflow excavation line. These considerations primarily apply to the overflow spillway of a rockfill dam, but also apply to other dam appurtenances. a. If the material excavated from the overflow spillway is suitable for use as embankment material in terms of quality and construction, there is no problem. However, recently, standards for embankment materials have become stricter, and there are many cases where a significant portion of the excavated material must be discarded. In such cases, the excavation line should be carefully reviewed to minimize the amount of cut and fill. b. There may be situations where the overall excavation volume needs to be reduced, or where the foundation of the entire or part of the overflow spillway does not reach solid bedrock due to hydraulic requirements. In these cases, the ground’s bearing capacity and deformation characteristics should be thoroughly investigated before designing an appropriate structure. c. If thin layers of weak soil are present, methods such as replacing them with plug concrete may be employed. d. When the overflow spillway excavation line is close to other structures, such as when it is parallel to a tunnel, the distance between them should be at least five times the tunnel’s inner diameter, as a general guideline. 3. 3.2 Excavation (1) Excavation

① Excavation shall be performed to the depth necessary to achieve the specified water permeability, shear strength, and foundation treatment, using the method most suitable for the ground conditions. Furthermore, debris, loosened rock fragments, and large irregularities on the excavated surface shall be removed, leveled, and the area shall be protected from rainwater and groundwater to ensure complete contact between the foundation and the embankment.

② Since visual inspection and further treatment of the excavation surface become difficult once earthwork begins, in addition to receiving an inspection from the construction supervisor immediately before starting earthwork, a safety assessment must be obtained from an expert.

③ Excavation methods and equipment used will vary depending on the geology, but in any case, excavation should not cause instability in surrounding areas. For soil foundations, for example, it is desirable to either take a sufficient excavation slope or stabilize the surrounding area using techniques such as wellpoint methods before excavation.

④ Rock, especially hard rock, is typically excavated using blasting, but as the planned depth is approached, the amount of explosives should be reduced to minimize disturbance of the rock mass.

⑤ In addition to minimizing rock disturbance, blasting should also aim to prevent the formation of large uneven surfaces, rockfall from the slope face, and spalling at the rock end. Drilling and reduced blasting techniques should be employed, and in cases where the rock face has numerous joints, the bench-cut method is effective.

⑥ The end shape of the excavation should preferably have a gentle slope at the connections on both sides. If a gentle slope is impractical due to topography, the entire connection should be shaped as a stepped form, and a sharp angle should be avoided as much as possible. Connections with a sharp angle are prone to cracking due to differential settlement in the vicinity of the apex.

⑦ Reverse slopes tilted towards the hillside are strictly prohibited. In such cases, the area should be excavated and removed. However, if it is localized and difficult to shape by excavation, it should be shaped using concrete.

⑧ Protruding rock portions should be removed by excavation as a general rule. However, for relatively small portions that are difficult to remove, they may be shaped by layering concrete. (Figure) 5. [ERROR] : 'choices' 1 2.7～ two One 5.4 mm pipe is installed vertically, and the surrounding area is backfilled with small gravel or loose stones while removing the mandrel, compacting the waterproofing layer. (A) When the discharge volume reaches an appropriate depth, another pipe is added and installed vertically, the mandrel is removed, and the waterproofing layer is compacted with the two pipes in place. After the waterproofing layer has risen to a thickness of 4～5 m, a high-concentration grouting material is injected at very low pressure through the pipe on the deeper side. In this case, the other pipe serves as a vent, and grouting is stopped when the grouting material begins to emerge from this pipe. (B) The injection pressure should be no more than 80% of the overburden pressure, and the concentration should be a water-cement ratio of 1 : 1～. 1. General Considerations
1.1 Scope
(1) A ratio of 0.5:1 (by weight) is appropriate. (A) When discharging from the entire bottom of the index trench, it should be primarily blocked by grouting. However, there is no need to index more than the water tightness required for the foundation, and increasing water tightness arbitrarily is uneconomical. (Ka) Therefore, if the foundation's permeability is improved within an acceptable range, grouting can be terminated even if there is some seepage. In this case, ditches are installed on both sides of the index trench, and two pipes are installed to grout at the point where they are backfilled to a suitable height, as in the case of significant seepage. (Ta) Initially, water is discharged from the exhaust pipe, and grouting is performed until a grout paste-like material comes out, followed by full-scale grouting. Also, in cases where sufficient drainage is not possible with drainage on both sides of the index trench, ditches are installed in the center of the index trench, and the same grouting method is applied. ⑤ Treatment of Fractures. Fractures or crushing in the foundation rock can lead to a lack of support, causing uneven subsidence or leakage, and can cause piping phenomena due to the outflow of fine particles. Small-scale fractures can be treated with grouting, but fractures with a clay layer of at least 50 cm in width require special treatment. Depending on the location and direction of the fracture, the vulnerable area is typically excavated to the deepest possible depth and replaced with concrete.
Na. In the case of a fil dam, the support problem is often less critical than in a concrete dam, but to prevent the softening of the fractured clay surface, prevent grout leakage, and ensure uniform stress by making the core contact surface the same as the surrounding rock mass, it is good to install a concrete cap over the entire length of the fracture appearing in the core trench.
Da. In addition to the aforementioned concrete cap, a deep index wall is required to limit the flow velocity by lengthening the infiltration path and prevent the outflow of fractured clay. The depth of the index wall is generally determined empirically based on the condition, location, angle, and direction of the fracture. The index wall is typically constructed by excavating a shallow shaft in the cross-section and filling it with water-tight concrete, and the contact surface with the rock mass is further reinforced by grouting. One is installed intersecting the grout curtain where the shaft is constructed, or two are installed, one upstream and one downstream. In the latter case, the upstream side is generally deeper, and the downstream side is about half as deep. These index walls are particularly frequently used in concrete dams.
⑥ Temporary Protection Measures for Weathered Rock
Ga. If the rock is exposed to the atmosphere, it will rapidly weather or swell due to groundwater. Therefore, it should be sufficiently protected before starting soil excavation. Methods include: (A) Before reaching the final excavation bottom, lower the drainage ditches on both sides of the index trench by more than 50 cm below the final excavation bottom to lower the groundwater level. Then, excavate and clean the final bottom, and immediately spray heated asphalt or a waterproof rubber coating onto the rock to form a waterproof membrane. (Na) Perform grouting in advance and plug grout near the excavation depth. Then, begin soil excavation in stages. Moreover, methods involving removing mortar spraying or other processes that must be removed before starting soil excavation should be avoided.
Na. In sandy slopes, erosion in the form of slumping due to rainfall is a problem. This is mainly due to the concentration of surface water in one location, and temporary drainage facilities should be sufficient, and a waterproof membrane should be formed on the sandy slope by spraying heated asphalt or a water-tight urethane rubber coating.
⑦ Soil Handling
Ga. The method and transportation method of soil should be determined in relation to the excavation method, excavation volume, dumping location, and area of the soil storage yard, and the loading and unloading equipment should be well balanced. At the bottom of the river, a route should be established for the construction machinery to easily evacuate during water discharge and blasting. The location of the soil storage yard is determined by the surrounding topography, transportation distance, and soil volume, but the capacity should take into account the increase or decrease due to excavation.
Na. If there is a risk of damage downstream due to the collapse and outflow of soil, it is necessary to establish a system for foundation treatment, groundwater exclusion, and exclusion of surface water from the surrounding area, as well as to take appropriate measures such as soil slope protection and backwater treatment, depending on the circumstances. When handling soil on the upstream side of the dam, it should be prevented from depositing in the outlet channel and impeding floodwater inflow. 3.4 Grout Injection (1) The construction method shall be determined based on the performance of the boring work or grout test. (2) Boring shall be performed rotationally using diamond bits or metal bits, etc. Groundwater level and leakage quantity shall be observed during boring advancement. (3) After boring is completed, a permeability test shall be performed before grouting. The pressure of the hydraulic test is typically low pressure. Apply 1.5 times for 5 to 10 minutes. (4) The grout pressure may be sufficient even when applying more than 10 times the weight of the rock above on hard rock. It is not necessary to exceed the maximum pressure when the grout injection volume starts to increase rapidly. (5) The concentration is used within the range of 1:10 to 1:1. The injection concentration usually starts from 1:3 to 1:5, and if injection does not occur, the concentration should be gradually diluted. (6) When there is surface leakage of the grout, the following methods should be used to prevent it. ① Plug the grout cap of the concrete. ② Block it with a rag or wedge. ③ Cover the surface with a layer of grout or mortar approximately 18mm thick. ④ Increase the concentration of cement pulp and stop grouting and solidify it at the point of surface leakage. ⑤ Height 1.5～ Approximately 6.0m of soil embankment shall be constructed, and grouting will be performed on the top of the embankment. (7) When grouting on top of the soil embankment, a packer that inserts casing to bedrock must be used. (8) Grouting methods include single-stage, packer, multi-stage, and overlapping grouting. (9) Suitable drilling machines for use in grout holes are ordinary boring machines or air percussion drilling rigs. (10) The grout pump must have properties sufficient to withstand the planned maximum injection pressure, but the pump type can be any. (11) Grout piping includes circulating systems and single line systems that do not take return flow. 3. 4.2 Bailing and Internal Well Cleaning (1) The bailing tool shall be used in accordance with the specifications stated in the design drawings, but the use of a bailing tool with a larger diameter than specified may be permitted. Grease or other lubricants shall not be applied or adhere to the bailing rod. Clean water should be used for bailing, and if reclaimed water is used, instructions from the supervisor shall be obtained. (2) After bailing to the planned depth, the bailing tool shall be slightly lifted from the bottom of the hole, and the water supply from the pump shall be increased while expelling the cuttings. At this time, the rod should be moved up and down by approximately 30-60 cm to bring the cuttings to the surface, and as much of the cuttings as possible shall be removed. (3) The bailing tool, casing, and hole diameter are 4. Referring to the table in Section 5.6, drag bits or Odex bits can be used when drilling through central clay or colluvial layers where coarse gravel or cobbles are mixed, preventing smooth drilling, or when it is necessary to inject space between the borehole wall and the casing. (4) During borehole cleaning, compressed air may also be used if there is a large amount of weathered material in the ground itself or if clay components with dispersive properties create lumps that cannot be completely removed with water alone. In this case, a diagonally cut steel pipe is attached to the end of a plastic hose or high-pressure hose and is inserted and lowered to clean the borehole. 3. 4. 2.1 Permeability Test (1) The leakage test using a leak-off tool, conducted immediately prior to injection in the bedrock, is performed for 15 minutes, recording the injection volume and pressure every 5 minutes. The test pressure is applied at 1 bar, unlike pressure tests for wellbore, which typically follow a low-pressure→high-pressure→low-pressure sequence. (2) The leak-off test conducted immediately prior to injection in the bedrock differs somewhat from permeability tests performed during the grouting design stage or permeability tests for pilot holes. The purpose of this test is to determine the permeability of the section to be injected, to refer to it when determining the initial w/c ratio, to roughly estimate the expected injection volume, or to evaluate whether the injection influence of previously injected holes in nearby locations has reached this far, i.e., to assess the effectiveness of interpolation. It also aims to confirm whether the injected water leaks to the ground surface or into adjacent holes, thereby preparing for potential leakage of the injected material. (3) Some may attempt to apply the same pressure as the subsequent construction injection pressure, but this is unnecessary. Water enters more easily than the injected material, and sending water with unnecessarily high pressure can actually lead to easier rock displacement than during injection. 3. 4. 2.2 Injection Pressure (1) The injection pressure should be maximized within a range where the strata do not displace or the elastic properties of the fracture system are not affected. Field injection tests should be conducted to determine the pressure at which fracturing or displacement occurs, and this value should be adopted as the appropriate injection pressure after reducing it by 85%. (2) The pressure applied to the injection well should be maximized within a range where the strata do not displace or the elastic properties of the fracture system are not affected. However, there is no definitive quantitative method for determining the appropriate injection pressure. This is because numerous factors influence the process, including the size, shape, orientation, and continuity of fractures, the strength of the rock mass, the length of the injection interval, and the injection effects of adjacent wells. In sedimentary rocks with horizontal bedding, it may not be possible to apply an injection pressure equal to the overburden pressure. Conversely, in massive, hard rocks, it may be possible to apply pressures up to 10 times the overburden pressure. (3) Determining a reliable maximum injection pressure involves conducting test grouting at each site, gradually increasing the pressure until fracturing occurs. During this test, a continuous supply of dilute grout with a low solids content should be maintained to prevent the fissures from being quickly blocked by the grout, and the fracturing pressure should be determined. It is beneficial to vary the length and depth of the injection interval during this process. The injection volume generally increases gradually in proportion to the increasing pressure at lower pressures, but increases sharply when the fracturing pressure is reached due to the creation of new fissures or the enlargement of existing ones. (4) The results of the injection test are shown in the figure. 5. By referring to a graph similar to Figure 2.11, an appropriate injection pressure can be determined. Generally, the appropriate injection pressure is set to approximately 85% of the fracturing pressure. (7) Re-injection ① When cement with a w/c ratio of 2 or leaner is used to complete the final injection, or when cement is injected with a w/c ratio of 1 or richer and more than 50 ℓ/m enters, re-injection is performed. In this case, re-injection should be started at least 24 hours after the completion of the first injection. ② This is because there is a high possibility that bleeding channels or voids will remain when using leaner injection materials, and in the latter case, where a large amount of material is injected with a richer mix, the injected material may spread in only one direction, resulting in insufficient filling of the cracks. ③ However, if there is leakage of the injection material, connection of the injection space, or displacement of the rock, re-injection is performed as an emergency measure, as the cracks are likely to be poorly filled. ④ Re-injection should be performed at least 24 hours after the completion of the first injection, to allow the injection material to set and the bled water to drain. However, if the injection is completed with a w/c ratio of around 2, the waiting time will not be that long. (8) Blasting Impact Assessment ① Determine whether blasting near the grouting site affects the setting of the injected material. ② Blasting can transmit waves to unset injection material, especially material under pressure, adversely affecting setting. However, it would be ideal if construction management at a dam construction site could complete all blasting before grouting, but this is often not the case. Therefore, grouting engineers are concerned about the impact of blasting vibrations. Most of the energy generated by the explosion of explosives is consumed in crushing the medium, and the remaining energy propagates through the medium, causing ground vibrations. ③ A simple way to measure this complex ground vibration effect in the field is to drill 2-3 boreholes at intervals from the blasting site (e.g., 100, 70, 50 m) and perform step-by-step permeability tests. After injecting each step, perform permeability tests again after a lapse of 1-2 days. Then, perform permeability tests immediately after blasting and compare them with the permeability test data taken immediately after re-drilling to determine if there is an impact from blasting, and if so, adjust the charge amount and blasting pattern. ④ At this time, permeability tests performed immediately after re-drilling and immediately after blasting can also be performed using a packer test, but the blasting effect can be determined by adjusting the valve to prevent water from overflowing the casing and measuring the hourly water inflow rate with a flow meter. (9) Well Cleaning ① If low pressure is applied to thoroughly uncleaned boreholes or injection holes, they will act as pressure relief wells, making it easy for leakage or piping to occur. Therefore, after completion of injection, the holes should be filled with w/c ratio added with 4% bentonite." "0.5:1 ratio grout should be used. Attach a 1″ steel pipe to the end of the injection hose, lower it to the bottom of the borehole, activate the injection pump to send the grout into the borehole, and raise the injection hose slowly as you fill the borehole. If subsidence occurs and the borehole is not completely filled, recharge it. ② Powdered cement should never be thrown into the borehole and rammed in with a long rod. Contrary to expectations, the powder will adhere to the borehole wall, creating a bridging effect and preventing the borehole from being completely filled. (10) Injection Effect Analysis ① On-site Effect Analysis. The grout injected into fractures, joints, and fractured zones in the bedrock cannot be visually confirmed. Therefore, it is impossible to overlook the evaluation of construction effects, considering the economic losses and structural damage caused by poor construction. Evaluation should be performed during construction and after construction. On-site evaluation is performed by experienced technicians at each stage of the work. Therefore, it is crucial to adjust the grout concentration based on periodic injection volume inspection data, judging factors such as permeability, geological conditions, connectivity, and leakage potential, to achieve the best injection effect. b. When using the interpolation method, it is necessary to determine whether to inject cold grout into the previously constructed injection holes between them. Record and review construction data daily on a longitudinal section, including the pre-construction Lu value of adjacent injection holes, injection pressure, cement injection volume per injection cycle, leakage or connectivity, and bedrock displacement. Carefully review the recorded data, as there will inevitably be parts that are unsatisfactory or raise concerns. c. If the design and construction involves two or more rows, each row should be prepared separately, with the same scale, and preferably on transparent paper to allow for overlay comparison. d. For blanket or consolidation grouting, draw circles on the plan view for each borehole and record various construction data within them. If there are two or more stages, draw them separately for each stage. Evaluation should begin with stage 1, reviewing not only the borehole itself but also its connectivity with adjacent boreholes, with particular attention to the data from the most recently constructed injection hole. In particular, pay close attention to the pressure test data performed immediately before injecting the recently constructed hole and examine whether the Lu value is approaching the target ground improvement value. It is necessary to thoroughly evaluate how much the Lu value in the test borehole has decreased with the interpolation method, considering the 1st and 2nd boreholes. ② Judgment of Injection Effect after Construction a. Physical Exploration (a) Compare the resistivity values of the two-dimensional electrical resistivity tomography or Schlumberger array electrical resistivity tomography data conducted before and after construction to analyze the construction effect of grouting. If necessary, conduct natural potential exploration in addition to two-dimensional electrical resistivity tomography to perform a composite interpretation. For consolidation grouting, perform permeability tests or elastic wave exploration to analyze the effects before and after construction. b. Permeability Test (a) The most commonly used method is to compare permeability test data before and after curtain grouting construction to confirm whether the cutoff wall has been improved to the target permeability. The test borehole location is selected in the center of the cutoff wall, and test boreholes should be arranged evenly, including areas where the injection effect is suspected and areas where it is considered to be going well, to ensure a comprehensive evaluation. (b) The test pressure applied in the permeability test should be 80% of the injection pressure applied during construction in the test section, which is considered reasonable. The question of how to determine when ground improvement values after construction are satisfactory has been debated for a long time. Even with the best technology, the best equipment, and excellent construction management, the conditions of the bedrock to be injected vary greatly, the same dam even differs from section to section, and the size of the bedrock cracks and the particle size range of the injection material are wide, resulting in diverse results. (d) When using Type I Portland cement as the injection material for ground improvement in bedrock, it is good to set the improvement target within the range of 3～7 Lu. However, it is most reasonable to determine the ground improvement target through a trial grouting process prior to the main grouting work. 3. 4.3 Material Procurement Plan 3. 4. 3.1 Construction Materials (1) The construction materials for the fill dam include materials excavated and transported from selected borrow areas and quarries, as well as excavated materials generated from excavation related to structures such as spillways during dam construction. ① Materials transported from borrow areas (including quarries). Borrow areas should be located in places where excavation and transportation can be aligned with the embankment construction process. When excavating the deep layers of the soil in the borrow area first, in accordance with the distribution of materials and the construction process, it may be unavoidable to temporarily deposit a portion of the upper layer through backfilling or stockpiling; this should be fully considered. b. In order to obtain high-quality materials suitable for the design conditions, a significant amount of topsoil often needs to be excavated from quarries or borrow areas. Therefore, when determining the quarry or borrow area, geological conditions, strata, and deposit conditions should be thoroughly investigated. If it is necessary to mix materials from multiple borrow sources to obtain materials suitable for the design, a temporary stockpile area should be prepared. ② Usable Materials. Materials generated during excavation for the construction of the embankment, spillway, pressure relief conduit, and other auxiliary structures are cheaper to excavate than to extract from borrow areas. Therefore, it is necessary to determine whether the materials are suitable for the design conditions and utilize them in the dam construction. The timing of generation should ideally coincide with the dam construction process and allow for immediate transportation; otherwise, they should be stockpiled or temporarily deposited before use. 3. 4. 3.2 Utilization Plan (1) Once the material source and available quantity are determined, a utilization plan should be established, considering factors such as material utilization rate and volume calculation coefficient. (2) Material Extraction ① After clearing and stripping the topsoil at the material extraction site, the excavated material should have an appropriate moisture content and gradation. ② Soil Material Extraction a. Whether to clear and strip the topsoil comprehensively or partially at the material extraction site shall be determined based on the construction process, the distribution and properties of the material. If the material is wet, pre-stripping the topsoil can allow it to dry through sun exposure or ventilation. In the case of a dam fill project, construction can take several years, and weeds or shrubs may regrow after topsoil stripping, so caution is required. b. Adjustment of Soil Material (a) Since the excavated material should have an appropriate moisture content and gradation, adjustment is necessary if it does not meet the required conditions in its natural state. The following are precautions when adjusting moisture content: ㉮ For wet materials, install side ditches around the borrow area to prevent surface water inflow, and also install drainage ditches to lower the groundwater level. Excavate with a lake dozer and dry the material through sun exposure or ventilation. In cold regions, frost heave may occur in the soil, so cover the embankment with a sheet or soil in advance to prevent this, and remove it before embankment construction. ㉯ For dry materials, water should be added to increase the moisture content. This can be done at the stockpile yard, during transportation, and at the embankment site. Watering methods include spraying with a hose, sprinkler, and water truck. ㉰ If the soil material in the borrow area has too much fine or coarse material and cannot be used, mix it with suitable material from another borrow area to achieve the gradation required by the design. Generally, a figure. 5. 3.1, fine-grained soil and crushed granite are layered and thinly placed on the preparation area. When the moisture content is slightly on the wet side of the optimum moisture content, mix with a truck shovel and adjust to the required gradation. (b) At this time, the layer thickness in the preparation area should be as thin as possible, limited by the minimum thickness required to spread the fine-grained material. This is because it can reliably adjust the gradation, promote drainage, and effectively remove organic impurities or oversized particles. The foundation and bottom surface of the preparation area should be sloped to consider drainage, and the stacking height should be 3~5 m, which is the appropriate excavation height of the used truck shovel. ③ Excavation of granular materials. Generally, granular materials are mostly deposited in rivers, so silty materials with high moisture content cannot be used as they are. In such cases, the water is diverted or the water level is lowered before excavation, or the materials are pre-treated to remove moisture. If the gradation does not meet the design conditions, a grizzly or screening plant is installed to adjust the gradation. ④ Excavation of rock materials. (a) Rock excavation without blasting. ㉮ The classification of rock types that can be excavated by a ripper is determined by the capabilities of the ripper and bulldozer, and the elastic wave velocity of the original ground is one criterion. (b) Other machinery. ㉮ Due to the recent increase in the size of machinery, rope-operated power shovels can excavate rock in the low-strength rock zone due to their impact force, so the use of these large machines should be considered based on the construction capacity. In addition, large rock breakers have appeared for excavating from medium-hard to hard rock, and while they are not suitable for single use for dam rock material excavation due to their construction capacity, they are used for small crushing work. b. Rock excavation by blasting. (a) Rock excavation methods using blasting are broadly classified into bench cut method, tunnel blasting method, and other methods. ㉮ Tunnel blasting. Tunnel blasting is a method used to excavate a large amount of rock by excavating a small cross-sectional tunnel in a quarry, installing a chamber, and blasting using a concentrated blasting method. It is used for pre-excavation, removal of thick weathered layers, and terrain where heavy machinery cannot be transported. Tunnel chambers are generally T-shaped, and the cross-sectional shape is based on the height. 1.5～ 1.6 m, width 0.9～ Sets the standard at 1.3 m. Bench cut blasting. Benches are constructed and drilling is performed on the generally level bench surface. A construction method involving vertical (or 70°) drilling with a large excavator equipped with drill bits of 7.6 cm or greater, followed by free-face blasting to gradually move the construction bench downward, is widely used because excavating a set amount to match the process can save labor. (3) Blasting Tests ① When quarry materials or transition materials are extracted from a quarry, blasting tests are conducted to examine effective material extraction methods. ② Blasting tests are performed to examine more economical extraction methods and methods for obtaining materials with an ideal gradation distribution when quarry materials or transition materials are extracted from a quarry. The tests are conducted several times depending on the blasting method, the amount and type of explosives used. These tests are carried out based on the required amount of rock and transition materials, typically when more than 100,000 m3 is needed. Therefore, if the required quantity is small, the tests are often simplified, for example, by utilizing rock outcrops to simply observe the rock fragmentation behavior due to blasting and investigate the amount of explosives. On the other hand, when a large quantity of rock and transition materials is required, detailed tests should be performed using the quarry as a principle. 3. 4. 3.3 Selection of Transportation Facilities (1) When selecting transportation facilities, consider site conditions, design conditions, construction schedule, economy, and versatility, and comprehensively review, referring to past construction data, to select the most advantageous option. (2) Transportation facilities at the Fil Dam include: ① Roads (including construction roads), ② Belt Conveyors, ③ Dedicated Rail Lines, ④ Aerial Ropeways, and ⑤ Special Equipment Vehicles. (3) Roads are most commonly used as transportation facilities at the Fil Dam. However, the transportation facilities mentioned in 2), 3), and 4) are subject to significant constraints regarding loading and unloading points. Vehicle 5) is suitable for small-scale transportation and performs well in areas with poor footing; it is available in wheeled (4-wheel or 6-wheel) and crawler types. Crawler-type dump trucks are towed by bulldozers. 4.5 m3 There is 7.0 m3 of it. 3. 4. 3.4 Selection of Material Extraction and Transportation Equipment (1) When selecting material extraction and transportation equipment, consider the geographical characteristics between the borrow area and the dam, as well as the construction plan. (2) The construction conditions for a fil dam are hardly ever the same, so when selecting equipment, you must understand the general trends and overview of equipment suitable for each construction condition. The following are some general precautions to consider when selecting equipment: ① In general, the larger the earthwork machinery, the greater its capacity, and the lower the unit cost per 1 m. ② When a daily or hourly production target is set, it is generally more cost-effective to combine equipment that can achieve that target capacity. ③ It is preferable to standardize transportation equipment within the same system. In particular, avoiding equipment combinations such as transporting the same excavated material simultaneously with dump trucks and scrapers, or where tractors and scrapers with significantly different speeds intersect, will reduce work efficiency. ④ Special equipment should be introduced after careful consideration. Equipment limited to specific tasks may become uneconomical if the annual utilization rate is low. Pay particular attention to this in sites where equipment import and export are difficult. ⑤ If one machine affects multiple other machines (e.g., loading or compaction equipment), take measures to prevent all work from being halted in the event of a breakdown of that one machine, or consider risk diversification. ⑥ Even when combining large-scale loading equipment with low transportation costs and similar transportation equipment, be careful to avoid combinations where there is insufficient dumping distance, making actual loading impossible or mechanically unfeasible. ⑦ Be aware of cases where the type of equipment is limited by design. 3. 4.4 Blasting (1) Blasting shall be carried out in accordance with the time, location, and method approved by the construction supervisor (or superintendent), and the contractor shall be responsible for any damage or loss caused by the blasting. (2) When the contractor performs blasting, a qualified and experienced blaster shall be assigned. (3) Blasting work shall be carefully performed to avoid damaging the bedrock outside the excavation plan line. (4) A fair plan shall be established to prevent adverse effects on nearby structures or grouting due to rock blasting. 3.5 Earthworks 3. 5.1 General Embankment (1) Embankment construction shall be carried out after the excavation inspection is completed and in accordance with the instructions of the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (2) Before constructing the embankment, the contractor shall prepare a construction plan and obtain approval from the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (3) The surface of the embankment shall be leveled horizontally, and compaction tests shall be carried out to determine the in-situ moisture content of the materials, the appropriate type of compactor, the number of compaction passes, the spreading thickness, and the method for adjusting the moisture content of impermeable materials before construction. (4) Embankment construction shall be carried out along the dam axis, and the materials for each section shall be homogeneous. Materials mixed with tree roots and other materials exceeding the maximum aggregate size shall be removed. (5) Unless otherwise specified, each layer of each section shall be constructed continuously and horizontally. (6) Compaction equipment shall be selected appropriately based on the soil type to achieve the required density, and compaction equipment that satisfies the density or impermeability requirements shall be used for corners. (7) Rock joints or areas around structures where rollers cannot access shall be adequately compacted with rammers or tampers. (8) Areas already compacted by rollers shall be... The fill material shall overlap by at least 0.3m in width. (9) The maximum rolling speed shall be 45km/h. (10) When a gap occurs temporarily during the filling process for drainage or other purposes, prior approval shall be obtained from the construction supervisor (or superintendent) before construction. The slope of the joint between the previously constructed section and the new section shall not exceed 1:4, and a key trench shall be installed in the transverse fill at this time. (11) If changes to the construction method are required due to changes in the conditions of the borrow area, material quality, or other circumstances, approval shall be obtained from the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (12) The filling shall be constructed under completely drained conditions, and any seepage water and hazardous materials from the foundation shall be removed. (13) The subsequent filling of the embankment shall be carried out in accordance with the specifications in the design documents or construction specifications; if not specifically stipulated, the cross-section and shape shall be according to the instructions of the construction supervisor (or superintendent). (14) Appropriate measures shall be taken to prevent saturation, drying, and freezing of the filling face when the construction is temporarily suspended, and saturated, frozen, and dried portions shall be removed and reconstructed. (15) The compaction of permeable materials is best achieved by spraying water and vibrating, but if it contains about 4% silt, construction becomes difficult and permeability may be lost, so caution is necessary. 3. 5.2 Rockfill (1) Rockfill refers to the construction using large rock (rock) materials with an average particle size of 150mm or greater in the permeable zone. (2) Blasting methods include stepped excavation and tunneling, and the most economical method should be adopted based on terrain, rock quality, excavating equipment, etc. (3) A quarry should have a size, front width, and suitable height that can be handled by construction machinery during initial blasting. (4) For large rocks, the leveling and spreading method or the dumping method is generally used, and for small rocks, the leveling and spreading method is generally used. (5) The layer thickness, lift thickness, watering method, and compaction method, etc. are determined according to the type and strength of the rock and the layer position within the dam. (6) In areas with permafrost, blasting is generally not permitted. (7) The leveling thickness per layer of rock material, when following compaction methods, shall be based on the maximum diameter. 1. General items 1.1 Scope "2.0x is appropriate," A factor of approximately 1.3 is generally adopted. Even when following the dump method, single-lift construction is not ideal, and a maximum of five times the maximum aggregate size should be used per lift. (8) The rock material, when crushed, should have a specified shear strength and permeability coefficient greater than 1×10-2mm/sec, should not release harmful substances due to chemical reactions, and should be hardened, solid, durable, and have low deformation. 3. 5.3 Impermeable Zone (1) Grading shall be performed horizontally across the entire planned construction section aligned parallel to the dam axis using a bulldozer or other approved equipment. (2) If the compaction surface is smooth, it shall be scraped before placing the next layer of grading to ensure good contact. (3) The moisture content of the material shall be the same in any lift. (4) The next lift shall not be placed before the compaction test is completed after compaction. (5) During grading work, rocks and defective soil with a maximum diameter of 150 mm and organic materials shall be removed. (6) Compaction equipment shall use a tamping roller, and the specifications shall comply with the construction specifications. (7) The grading thickness and number of compaction passes shall be based on the results of the compaction test, but the minimum number of compaction passes shall be 10 or more. (8) If the pore water pressure increases abnormally during construction, adjust the construction speed appropriately. (9) When temporarily suspending work, the compaction surface of the impermeable zone shall be leveled and protected from surface water. (10) The surface compaction ratio of the impermeable material shall be 95% or more. (11) When constructing the impermeable zone on bedrock, the following precautions shall be taken. ① Since the bedrock and clay must be in close contact, the moisture content of the impermeable material shall be in a moist state 2～3% wetter than the optimum moisture content. ② The initial grading material on the bedrock shall be well-graded silty soil passing the No.4 sieve. Any stones remaining (4.76mm) shall not be included. ③ Due to the difficulty of roller compaction at the bedrock interface, it should be compacted with a rammer or tamper, with a spreading thickness of 50～100mm as a general rule. ④ The thickness to be compacted with a rammer or tamper shall be up to the thickness that does not damage the underlying bedrock by tamping and roller compaction. 3. 5.4 Filter (1) Ensure that material separation does not occur during filter placement. (2) During construction, materials from other zones shall not be mixed into the filter layer, impairing the filter function. (3) Filter installation shall be performed horizontally, simultaneously with adjacent zones. (4) The installation width, placement, and compaction methods for vertical or sloped filters shall be approved by the pre-construction supervisor (or inspector). 3. 5.5 Transition Zone (1) The placement of the transition zone's gradation shall be designed from the quarry outwards, considering particle size and permeability, ensuring that permeable materials are used to prevent abrupt changes in material properties near the center of the embankment. (2) The spreading thickness of the transition zone is typically based on the maximum particle size of the material used. 1. General Matters 1.1 Scope of Application Approximately 1.2 times is suitable, generally. It should be done at 1.3 times the scale (3). Since the transition is wider than the filter, the material should have sufficient shear strength for the structural stability of the body. 3. 5.6 Slope Protection Works (1) Slope paving shall be constructed using the most suitable method for the material to ensure the stability of the design purpose. To achieve this, meticulous construction is required to minimize changes in the pavement base settlement. (2) Asphalt paving requires appropriate asphalt distribution and sufficient compaction (air void ratio of 3～5%). Vibratory smooth rollers are effective compaction equipment. (3) In the case of concrete paving, the construction of the bedrock masonry that forms the basis of the pavement should be started approximately 2 months after the initial settlement of the main rockfill is complete. (4) Prior to concrete paving, a joint filling concrete with an average thickness shall be applied to the surface of the bedrock masonry. Apply to a thickness of 0.1m or less (5). It is recommended to lay the concrete pavement 2 months after the dry stone masonry. The height of the partition is 1 time. The height shall be approximately 0.4m, and sufficient compaction shall be performed. (6) Rock slope protection structures shall use larger aggregate on the surface and smaller aggregate internally to prevent the suction of base material. (7) Rock placement shall be carefully considered regarding aggregate size to adequately protect the earthwork section against sudden water level drops or wave action. (8) Earthwork slopes shall be adequately compacted to prevent soil detachment and finished neatly. (9) Operations such as grading, leveling, and seeding shall be in accordance with the provisions of “Chapter 3, Common Works.” (10) Any matters not specified in the above specifications shall be in accordance with the contract specifications. 3.6 Overflow Structure (1) The spillway channel construction plan shall be implemented after obtaining approval from the Construction Supervisor (or Resident Engineer) in advance. (2) If the geological conditions change during the excavation of the spillway channel foundation, report to the Construction Supervisor (or Resident Engineer) and follow their instructions. (3) If the excavated material can be used for the dam body, develop an excavation plan considering the dam construction plan. (4) Overexcavation of rock, where the rock encountered is beyond the specified excavation line, shall be backfilled with concrete at the expense of the contractor, following the instructions of the Construction Supervisor (or Resident Engineer). (5) The height of concrete placement in a single pour for the crest spillway shall be in accordance with the specifications and the instructions of the Construction Supervisor (or Resident Engineer). (6) If the bottom and slopes of the approach channel to the spillway are unstable against the approach velocity, or if the approach channel causes a dangerous hydraulic condition to the dam and outlet works, lining shall be installed. (7) The foundation of the spillway control structure shall be made watertight by grouting or other methods. (8) All expansion joints in the upstream portion of the control structure’s east/west centerline shall use waterstops. (9) The sidewalls of the spillway and spillway channel shall be either structurally stable in themselves or be closely attached to a stable and solid bedrock foundation. (10) Waterstops and expansion joints shall be installed in the transverse direction of the spillway channel. (11) Drainage pipes shall be installed inside the downstream portion of the spillway control grout curtain and within the spillway channel sidewalls to collect and discharge seepage water to a safe location. (12) The gate hoisting mechanism shall be equipped with a backup power supply as a standard emergency measure. (13) The dam gate shall be designed to open and close reliably and to have the necessary watertightness and durability. 3.7 Intake Structure Work (1) The intake structure shall be constructed at the location designated on the drawings, and if variations in soil conditions are found during excavation, instructions from the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor) shall be followed. (2) The excavated side slope in the transverse direction of the conduit shall have a slope that prevents slope failure even in the event of rapid water level drawdown, or protective works shall be installed to prevent the intake structure from being buried due to soil collapse. (3) For the approach channel, a cutoff wall shall be installed to prevent leakage and piping, and if the structure is modified due to soil variations, approval from the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor) shall be obtained. (4) Appurtenances installed in the intake structure (screen, gate, valve, etc.) shall be inspected for fabrication details to ensure they do not interfere with the construction of the civil structure, and mutual agreement shall be reached. (5) Metal fittings embedded in concrete structures shall be accurately embedded during the first concrete placement and inspected by the Construction Supervisor (or Supervisor) after installation. (6) Steel structures such as trunnions, spindles, and winches shall comply with the specifications. (7) Any matters not specified in these specifications shall be governed by the specifications. 3.8 Festival Construction 3. 8.1 Construction Equipment (1) Considering construction period, material properties, work quantity, design conditions, site conditions, construction process, and construction methods, the type and number of construction equipment such as excavators, loading machines, transport machines, and compactors are determined and managed. ① Excavators include: bulldozers, shovel-type excavators, scrapers, and wheel excavators. Among excavators, bulldozers are used not only for excavation but also for felling, land clearing, short-distance soil transport, scraper towing, embankment compaction, road maintenance, and job site cleanup. Therefore, when selecting a model, bulldozers to be used other than excavation work should be considered. b. Shovel-type excavators are used as auxiliary equipment for bulldozers in the initial stage of excavation and in narrow places with operational constraints. Scrapers are not often used in large dams, but can be applied depending on the terrain and geology. Wheel excavators are machines that can continuously excavate in conjunction with belt conveyors, and should be selected after considering the terrain and geology of the construction site, and comprehensively reviewing transportation. ② Loading machines include: tractor shovels and shovel-type excavators. Tractor shovels are dedicated loading machines, while shovel-type excavators are primarily used for excavation but can also be used for loading. Traditionally, shovel-type excavators have been generally used for the excavation of earth and the loading of dam fill materials. 0.6～ A 2.0 m³ power shovel is being used. Tractor shovels are more versatile and maneuverable than shovel-type excavators, but they lack pushing force, so a bulldozer should be used as an auxiliary machine when unloading blasted rock. (A) Tractor Shovels ㉮ are classified into caterpillar and wheeled types based on their traveling method. Caterpillar-type shovels are slower in speed and maneuverability than wheeled types, but they have greater pushing force, allowing them to move large amounts of soil and operate in uneven terrain. Wheeled types are effective when the work site is scattered or frequent movement is required. (B) Shovel-type excavators ㉮ are often used as excavating or loading machines. They have a smaller work area than other machines, and the excavator body can be converted into various machines such as power shovels, backhoes, draglines, and clamshells by replacing attachments, making them versatile. They are therefore widely used for excavating and loading foundation ground, excavating and loading riverbed materials, excavating and loading unsuitable topsoil, and for other construction road work or slope construction. ③ Transport machinery includes dump trucks, scrapers, and belt conveyors, and dump trucks are often used in dam construction. (A) Dump Trucks (A) Recently, dump trucks have been increasingly used in dam construction due to its large scale. Generally, dump trucks are divided into ordinary dump trucks (under 11t) and heavy dump trucks (over 11t), and their advantages and disadvantages are as follows. ㉮ Ordinary Dump Trucks (under 11t). Advantages include no transport restrictions, easy procurement, easy adjustment of the number of units, and easy response in case of failure. Disadvantages include limited load capacity, which can lead to congested transport routes and work areas when many units are deployed, more operators than heavy dump trucks, making labor management more difficult, and the need to reinforce the loading box depending on the material being transported. ㉯ Heavy Dump Trucks (over 11t). Advantages include the ability to transport large volumes with fewer units, resulting in less overall time loss, higher stability of transport routes and work areas, and fewer operators. The large loading box makes loading easy and allows the use of large loading machines. Disadvantages include the inability to travel on general roads, high construction and maintenance costs for construction roads, and difficulty in procuring parts. The impact on the transport volume is significant in case of vehicle failure. (B) Scrapers ㉮ have excavating, transporting, and spreading functions, and are generally divided into carryall scrapers, which are towed by a tractor, and motor scrapers, which have a tractor integrated into the unit. Carryall scrapers are short-distance excavating, loading, and transporting machines and are more capable of traveling on rough roads than motor scrapers and are suitable for use in unstable ground or on steep slopes. Motor scrapers have lower excavation force than carryall scrapers but are superior for long distances. A characteristic of scrapers is that they can perform construction consistently from excavation to spreading, and the construction and maintenance of traffic routes are easier than when using dump trucks. They are unsuitable for cases involving hard rock or boulders. (C) Belt Conveyors ㉮ are suitable for cases where there is a large difference in elevation between the material extraction point and the embankment site, and where the construction of temporary roads is difficult. Once installed, they can continuously transport materials, reducing labor required for transport, but they have the disadvantage of being difficult to adapt to changes in construction volume. ④ Compaction machinery includes large tampers, vibratory rollers, and tire rollers, and small compactors, rammers, and air tampers, as well as dump trucks and bulldozers. When selecting a machine type, select one that is suitable for the properties of the fill material, has excellent constructability, and has performance that meets design conditions and fill criteria.
