Eight. 2.1 Equipment Selection (1) The construction equipment shall be selected considering the construction period, properties of materials, work quantity, design conditions, site conditions, construction process, and construction methods. ① Grading Equipment. Grading equipment generally utilizes bulldozers, and graders are used as auxiliary equipment for leveling unevenness on embankments. When scrapers or bottom-dump trucks are used for transportation, direct grading is performed, and generally, grading machines are used at this time. The specifications and number of bulldozers are determined by the embankment speed, embankment height, and also considering the type of material and the area of the embankment to select an appropriate one. ② Compaction Equipment. Compaction equipment for soil materials includes tire rollers, vibratory rollers, tamping rollers, vibrating compactors, rammers, and air tampers. In addition, bulldozers, dump trucks, and wheel loaders are also used in some cases. Furthermore, rock materials are placed by dumping without compaction. Regardless of the type, the compaction equipment that satisfies the required design values depends on the grading thickness and number of compaction passes, so it is generally determined by conducting trial compaction. a. To select 2-3 suitable machines based on soil conditions or specified compaction methods, and then make a final decision after trial compaction is recommended. The operating speed of the compaction equipment may be regulated depending on the case. ③ Moisture Content Adjustment and Gradation Adjustment Equipment. Lake dozers are used for moisture content adjustment or gradation of soil materials, and removing over-voltage parts, while water trucks are used for moisture content adjustment. Harrow and plow are also used in some cases. There are also special cases using a dryer for moisture content adjustment. Furthermore, rippers are used to agitate the surface of the embankment in the permeable zone, and monitors are used for watering. Lake and rippers are generally mounted behind the bulldozer used for grading. A dedicated lake dozer with a lake mounted on the front of the bulldozer is used to remove oversized particles from the fill material. 3. Eight. [ERROR] : 'choices' 3. 8. 2.3 Soil Material Construction (1) When constructing soil materials, inspections of the spreading and leveling thickness, removal of oversized aggregates, and compaction to achieve the required quality of the embankment shall be performed.  An inspection must be carried out before leveling the next layer after compaction is complete. ① General Provisions a. Inspection of Spreading and Leveling Thickness (a) Routine inspection of the spreading and leveling thickness is conducted by checking the construction area of the construction block and the number of vehicles. Monthly embankment height is checked using level surveying, and the spreading and leveling thickness is inspected per layer based on the monthly embankment volume. b. Spreading and Leveling Direction (a)  The spreading of fill materials shall generally be constructed parallel to the dam axis; however, in permeable random fill areas, there is no need to set a direction. c. Removal of Oversized Aggregates (a) The regulation for oversized aggregates is typically half the spreading and leveling thickness, but it is stipulated as one-third to two-thirds depending on the specific conditions of each dam. Oversized aggregates are removed using a lake dozer or screen plant in the borrow area, finely crushed weathered rock is spread on the embankment surface, and workers remove them from the embankment surface. d. Compaction (a) The speed of the compaction equipment is predetermined, and the number of compaction passes is inspected based on the area of the construction block, the compaction width and speed of the compaction vehicle, etc., as the total compaction time. Compaction work should overlap the previously compacted area by 30-50 cm. At the boundary of zones, the compaction machines of adjacent zones should overlap each other by approximately 20 cm. Also, compaction should be performed to the original ground by driving the compaction vehicle to the interface with the original ground to ensure sufficient compaction. The compaction direction should generally be the same as the spreading and leveling direction. e. Inspection After Compaction (a) An inspection must be carried out before leveling the next layer after compaction is complete. This inspection includes regular quality control tests and observation of the compaction area by the construction supervisor to confirm the adequacy of compaction. Particular attention should be paid to the interface with the original ground, the boundary between adjacent zones, and the traffic routes of transport equipment. In the waterproofing section, before leveling the next layer, scrape away any wheel tracks or flattened surfaces created by transport vehicles to ensure proper bonding with the next layer. f. Rain Protection Measures (a) The number of workable days for embankment construction based on weather conditions in a roller dam is a very important factor. Rain protection measures include the following: ㉮ Road Maintenance (Maintain the access road with asphalt paving, lime soil, or crushed stone to allow for use even immediately before rainfall.) ㉯ Borrow Pit Maintenance (Compact disturbed areas with plate rollers or tire rollers to prevent water infiltration.) ㉰ Embankment Surface Maintenance (Use plate rollers to smooth and compact the embankment surface to ensure efficient drainage and prevent water penetration.) ㉱ For areas where materials with high moisture content are produced, consider installing a temporary storage area for mixing with granular materials. g. Winter Embankment Construction (a) Embankment construction can be performed up to temperatures of -4 to -6 °C (there are cases where work has been performed up to -12 °C), but compare the dry density at 0 °C with the dry density at 24 °C. To prevent the fill from freezing, it is recommended to continuously place fill material 24 hours a day, 7 days a week, as the value is low at 0.1 tf/m3. For example, the Kenny Dam in Canada mixed 1% salt to lower the freezing point during construction.

A. Construction of the Dryer (a) When the moisture content is drier than required, the permeability of the fill material increases, so measures such as switching to nighttime work, watering, or increasing the weight of the compaction equipment should be taken.

B. Construction of the Impervious Core Layer (a) Compaction of the impervious core layer should be performed parallel to the dam axis using a compaction roller. Generally, compaction of the abutments is difficult with compaction rollers, and there is a risk of destroying the foundation bedrock, so small compaction machines are used for abutment compaction. (b) However, small compaction machines have low compaction efficiency, and the compaction effect is generally small. Therefore, it is common to first place fill material in the abutments and create a slope so that the slope prevents damage to the bedrock and allows compaction with a roller to approach the foundation more closely.

C. Smoothing (a) When constructing the impervious core layer, smoothing the core material should be performed parallel to the dam axis; smoothing the material perpendicular to the dam axis (upstream and downstream direction) is not recommended.

D. Compaction (Dynamic Compaction) (a) Compaction by roller should be performed parallel to the dam axis, similar to smoothing. In particular, avoid compaction in the upstream and downstream directions of the dam when using a tire roller. However, there may be cases where compaction is performed in the upstream and downstream direction of the dam to contact the foundation. In such cases, sufficiently disturb the compaction surface before smoothing the next layer to ensure good adhesion between the layers. (b) After the required width of compaction is completed, when moving to the adjacent next compaction area, widen the width by approximately 30-50 cm to overlap the completed compaction area and prevent any uncompacted areas from remaining. The fill shape should be almost horizontal or slightly sloped upstream and downstream to ensure good drainage. (c) If the shear strength of the surface is drastically reduced by compaction (e.g., in soils containing weathered mica schist), the center may be slightly lowered to prevent the activity of the surface passing through the area of weakened shear resistance. In this case, pay attention to drainage. (d) When installing a passage across the impervious core layer for excavation, grouting, or material transportation, the longitudinal slope should generally be no steeper than 3:1. If fill is to be placed in areas that are behind schedule, cut the preceding fill section at least 1 m deep and bring the two sections into close contact.

E. Compaction of High Moisture Content Soil Materials (a) Composite Compaction Method ㉮ Tamping rollers or tire rollers are mainly used for compaction of soil materials. When the moisture content of the material is relatively high, the soil may become lodged between the tines of the tamping roller, making compaction difficult, so a tire roller is used. However, this can result in problems such as a glossy compaction surface, poor adhesion between layers, and uneven density in the depth direction. These drawbacks can be overcome by using a combination of tamping rollers. That is, first use a tire roller to compact the soil layer sufficiently to increase its bearing capacity, and then use a tamping roller to compact it, resulting in uniform density and improved adhesion between layers. (b) Wet Compaction Method ㉮ Materials with high moisture content are compacted using compaction equipment with low ground pressure, such as a dozer or tractor. In this case, carefully consider the foundation shape, the width of the impervious core layer, and air conditions to prevent settlement. 3. 8. 2.4 Installation of Permeable Materials (1) Drain Installation ① Drains are installed by either laying them parallel to the existing embankment layers or by first constructing the embankment and then excavating and backfilling with drain material. A. General Provisions (a) Since drains are primarily intended for drainage, they are often used in conjunction with filters. When this is the case, filter-related precautions should also be considered, and the following precautions should be taken during drain installation. ㉮ After rainfall, the drain installation surface must be inspected, and any sediment such as clay particles or debris deposited on the surface should be removed. ㉯ During construction, prevent adjacent materials from mixing into the drain material. ㉰ After the first layer of embankment is completed, perform a water saturation test to check the permeability. ㉱ Drain edges are prone to loosening, so compact the area around the edges thoroughly, as if over-compacting. B. Single Drain Installation (a) Drains are installed by either laying them parallel to the existing embankment layers or by first constructing the embankment and then excavating and backfilling with drain material. Surface thickness (a) The surface thickness of the transition is based on the maximum aggregate size of the material used. 1. Compaction of Transition (a) Tire rollers or vibratory rollers are used for the compaction of transition materials, and the recent trend is to use vibratory rollers more often. It is said that compaction after watering or watering after compaction results in less settlement during reservoir storage. C. Density Management (a) For transition materials with small particle sizes, the sand replacement method is used to measure density, while the water replacement method is used for materials with larger particle sizes. The following method is recommended for combined use. (b) First, weigh approximately 10 (n) transport vehicles to calculate the average material transport quantity W (t/vehicle) per vehicle. Then, perform leveling measurements after spreading and compacting 3-5 layers to calculate the fill height H (m), and then calculate the construction area A (m2) on a plan view. D. Construction (a) The construction of transition materials containing a relatively large amount of fine particles should be carried out by spreading, leveling, and compacting to prevent future settlement. When spreading and leveling, material separation may occur like a filter, so dump at appropriate intervals to prevent this. However, if it is not possible to distinguish between rock material and transition material in a quarry, the properties mentioned above can be used to spread and level from the dam side towards the outer side of the embankment to push the oversized transition material into the rock zone. In this case, a lake dozer is used as the spreading and leveling machine. (4) Rock Zone Construction ① When constructing rock material, the ground surface should be leveled with a bulldozer to facilitate the operation of transport vehicles, and when placing the material, the boundary between the foundation ground and the transition zone should not be changed abruptly. E. General Provisions (a) During construction, the surface of each lift ㉮ is leveled with a bulldozer to facilitate the operation of rock material transport vehicles, and in some cases, it is leveled with rock debris. Sometimes, the surface of the spreading layer becomes finer due to compaction work or machine traffic. In such cases, permeability, post-reservoir settlement, and required shear strength may be compromised, so water should be injected to mix the fine particles into the voids between the rock material or the surface should be scraped up with a ripper. (b) Boundary construction with transition, etc. ㉮ When placing rock material, the boundary with the foundation ground or the transition zone should not be changed abruptly. That is, if the foundation ground is composed of soil material, a filter layer should be installed or, as a precaution, the rock material should be covered with as much fine rock as possible. The boundary with the transition material should also be tested periodically to ensure that this material does not mix into the rock material. (c) Winter Construction ㉮ If the temperature drops below freezing, the watering water will freeze, resulting in incomplete processing, and work in snowy conditions will also be likely to be incomplete. Therefore, in areas with heavy snowfall and cold temperatures, construction should generally not be carried out during the winter. (d) Construction Management ㉮ The stability of the material in the form of loose blocks and the boundaries of each zone should be managed, and the density should be measured using the same method as for the density measurement of transition materials. B. Spreading Thickness (a) The spreading thickness per layer of rock material should be based on the maximum particle size when compacting. 1. General Matters 1.1 Scope of Application A factor of 2.0 is appropriate, generally. Approximately 1.3 times the maximum aggregate size is used. In the case of blasting, up to five times the maximum aggregate size can be handled in a single lift. There are three methods for placing (rock) fill: ① Blasting method, ② Spreading and compaction method, and ③ A combination of the two, called blasting-natural compaction method. For convenience, ① is referred to as the high-lift method (blasting placement with a lift height exceeding 4 m), ② as the spreading and compaction method, and ③ as the low-lift method (blasting placement with a lift height of 1～4 m). Recently, as crushed materials have smaller, harder particles, the spreading and compaction method has been more frequently adopted than the high-lift method. ㉮ High-Lift Method. This method is better with higher lifts. It requires a minimum haul road and is considered to achieve dense compaction for the following reasons: When material is placed by blasting, fine particles, which are easily susceptible to settlement, tend to concentrate on the upper layer of the lift. The higher the lift, the greater the blasting energy. Sharp, angular fragments of rock material that would cause settlement due to future loading are broken when the material rolls down a long slope. These conditions must be met, and the material must be hard and have a low percentage of fines. ㉯ Low-Lift Method. This method compacts the material through blasting energy, spreading and compaction work, and the passage of transport vehicles. Since the effect of blasting is reduced when the material is fine, this method is adopted when mechanical compaction is expected. In this method, watering is generally not performed during placement, although it may be done in some cases. To maximize the compaction effect of the transport vehicles, the entry path should be changed occasionally, and the surface of the previously placed lift should be leveled to allow smooth travel. After the vehicle passes, the surface is smoothed, and before bonding it to the next layer, it must be roughened up with a ripper. This method and the spreading and compaction method may result in a height difference of one or several layers between the previously placed section and the currently placed section. Also, the slopes of the previously placed section are not compacted, and separated aggregate particles tend to accumulate on the slopes. These aggregate particles are removed, and the slope is cut back to a well-compacted area, and the material is then collapsed and placed on top of the existing lift to ensure a uniform fill. ㉰ Spreading and Compaction Method. This method involves spreading the material to a thickness within the effective depth of compaction and compacting it using equipment such as a medium bulldozer (approximately 20 t), a tire roller (approximately 50 t), and a flat-bodied (pan-type) vibratory roller or a vibratory tire roller (5～13 t). Tire rollers are relatively suitable for fine-grained materials, and their effective range is relatively shallow. Vibratory rollers are effective for aggregate materials containing large lumps, and their effective depth is It can reach approximately 2.0 m. However, when compacting materials with a high proportion of fine particles using a vibratory roller, the fine particles tend to float upwards, creating a weaker layer, so caution is needed. The layer thickness varies depending on the material and equipment, but it is generally set at 1-2 times the maximum particle size. The spreading thickness depending on the compaction equipment is generally 60 cm or less for tire rollers, around 1 m for medium bulldozers, and varies depending on the weight for vibratory rollers. The range is approximately 0.5～2 m. As mentioned previously, the compacted surface becomes smooth, so the layer needs to be scraped and leveled before placing the next layer. However, when using a vibrating roller to apply a thin layer of about 50 cm, close compaction between the lower and upper layers is possible, so scraping is not necessary. In the spread-and-compact method, watering without pressure (무압수) or spraying (사수) may be performed before compaction. 3. 8.3 Slope Finishing and Rock Placement (1) The batter shall be adequately compacted and finished to prevent surface collapse. (2) The batter shall be excavated slightly beyond the specified slope dimensions, thoroughly compacted with a roller, and then trimmed to the specified grade using a bulldozer or manual labor. Rock placement shall be constructed to adequately protect the batter against sudden water level drops or wave action. The gradation of the surface rock material shall be adjusted in advance at the quarry, and construction shall be carried out slightly after the batter work, transporting the material with a winch-equipped truck, pushing it up from below with a bulldozer, or installing haul truck rails at the same elevation and gradually raising the rails while transporting. 3. To finalize the mix design, structure, and construction methods of 8.4 Asphalt Paving (1), field testing and compaction shall be performed concurrently with the waterproofing wall installation. Generally, compaction is carried out with vertical and horizontal finishing. ① Compaction. It is recommended that waterproofing wall installation be performed simultaneously during compaction, and the two common compaction methods are as follows: (a) Vertical Finishing: This method involves compacting and finishing the slope in the vertical direction. Generally, the minimum radius of curvature for compaction work is approximately 25 m, and curved sections should be joined. (b) Horizontal Finishing: This method involves compacting and finishing the slope perpendicularly to the slope direction. Generally, the minimum plan radius for compaction work is approximately 15 m, and curved surfaces can be constructed as is. ② Connection to Structures. General Matters (a) It should be thoroughly considered that concrete structures and asphalt concrete are not fundamentally fully bonded, and construction should be performed accordingly. b. Connection to Inspection Gallery (a) The connection between the inspection gallery and the bottom of the waterproofing wall and the seepage control wall should preferably be made as straight or with a gentle curve as possible. 3.9 Construction Management (1) Dam construction shall be managed in compliance with relevant laws and regulations, specifications, standards, and other applicable regulations, using reasonable and effective methods. (2) Dam construction can only achieve the quality of the dam as designed, within the specified construction period, and economically through perfect construction preparation, meticulous construction planning, and thorough construction management. Since construction management is closely linked with construction planning and preparation, it is possible and necessary to manage construction through and by these elements (construction planning and preparation). (3) Construction management is primarily divided into quality management, progress management, and cost management. To specialize and efficiently supplement this primary division, a secondary management division is also used, encompassing detailed aspects such as material management, labor management, equipment management, facility management, safety management, environmental management, technical management, and financial management. (4) For construction management, the construction preparation status should be checked in advance, and if there are any items that are not or insufficiently prepared, they should be urged and guided to ensure complete preparation. The construction plan should be analyzed and thoroughly understood, and if there are any inconsistencies or unreasonable parts in the plan, they should be revised and supplemented. In other words, construction preparation, construction planning, and construction management operate and are promoted in a mutually reinforcing manner. However, above all, it is important to comply with relevant laws and regulations, KSF regulations, and specifications, and to manage accordingly. 3.10 Quality Control (1) Quality control in the construction of filter dams involves controlling the construction to ensure that the dam is built to the quality standards specified in the design. There are quality specification methods and construction methods, and a combined specification method that combines these two methods. These methods each have their own advantages and disadvantages, so they are adopted and managed considering the nature of the project, scale, soil conditions, and other on-site circumstances, as well as the advantages and disadvantages of the methods. (2) The quality of a filter dam is largely determined by the filter materials and construction methods. The “quality specification method” involves establishing quality criteria for the construction results before construction and managing the quality after construction based on whether it meets the established quality criteria; this is a commonly used method. The “construction method” involves managing the construction by strictly adhering to the construction methods (such as voltage application type, voltage recovery, voltage speed, and fill thickness) to achieve the quality standards specified in the design. This method is effective when there is no change in the moisture content of the soil and is limitedly used when quality inspection is difficult for materials like gravel and pebbles, or when the process is delayed. (3) Therefore, considering the advantages of each quality control method and taking into account the nature of the project, construction scale, soil conditions, and other on-site circumstances, select the appropriate method. 3. 1 0.1 Quality Control Methods (1) Quality control methods include compaction control methods, saturation control methods, air void control methods, and strength control methods. Since each method has its own characteristics and advantages and disadvantages, it is desirable to define and manage 2-3 standard values. ① Dry Density Control Method. This method is commonly used, and it specifies that the ratio of the dry density of the embankment to the maximum dry density achieved by compaction (compaction ratio) is above a specified value, and the allowable moisture content is within a specified range based on the optimum moisture content. In other words, this method defines the compaction ratio and allowable moisture content. ② Saturation or Air Void Control Method. This method has the advantage of being applicable to the moisture content of all soils. However, as the moisture content decreases, a greater compaction energy is required. Conversely, if the moisture content is high, it can reach the allowable limit with less energy, resulting in a pass at a weak strength level, making it impossible to confirm whether the embankment's safety and construction-required strength are obtained. Therefore, when defining this method, it is desirable to simultaneously define an allowable moisture content that can obtain the required strength. ③ Strength Control Method. This method is suitable for fill materials (sand, gravel, riprap, etc.) with little expansion and strength degradation due to water permeability. In particular, gravel and riprap are often difficult to measure dry density, making this method convenient. This method does not have a general strength criterion and must be determined on-site. 3. 1 A method of performing a voltage test on the fill based on one of the quality control methods specified in section 0.2 of the construction regulations and procedures, and managing to strictly comply with the regulations, specifically defining fill installation thickness, voltage testing equipment type, voltage recovery, and voltage speed, is particularly suitable for compaction of gravel, riprap, etc. 3. 1 Leveraging the strengths of each method within Section 0.3 of the combined specification method, this approach efficiently utilizes both quality specification and construction methods by performing construction according to construction methods and managing fill quality through quality specifications. Managing the quality of dam embankment construction using this method is considered the most desirable. As described above regarding quality control methods, even when managed according to this method, practical quality control in the field relies on observation and testing. 3. 1 In the construction of 0.4 Observation Management Fill Dams, the most important and primary management is observational management. The condition of the borrow area, which is the starting point of the dam construction work, namely the uniformity of the soil, engineering properties, moisture content, and the presence of foreign matter, is primarily managed through visual observation. The main observation items in the borrow area are: ① Discrimination and suitability of engineering properties of soil for each purpose (e.g., core clay, general embankment, filter), uniformity; ② Soil moisture condition (within permissible moisture content or excessive); ③ Observation of the presence of organic matter such as tree roots, and the degree of inclusion of gravel and stones. Initially, the usability of the soil in its current state is determined and actions are taken (allowing excavation, loading, and transportation if usable, or stopping work if not usable), and samples are collected and tested for management. At the construction site, the permissible moisture content of the transported soil, spreading thickness, and compaction status are observed, and they are initially managed accordingly, and samples are collected and tested for subsequent management. 3. 1 0.5 Management through Testing (1) Soil tests for quality control are divided into material tests and control tests. Material tests are performed to select fill materials during the design phase, and are generally not performed during construction since the data is used as is. However, material tests should be performed to manage quality when the borrow source changes or when different soil types are found even within the same borrow source. Quality control tests include moisture content measurement, compaction test, in-place density test, and permeability test. These tests are performed at the frequency specified for each item according to test standards (KSF), specifications, and test criteria. ① Moisture Content Measurement a. The measurement of soil moisture content is performed in accordance with KSF 2306 by drying the sample in an oven at a temperature of 110±5℃ and expressing the ratio of the mass of water evaporated from the wet soil to the dry mass of the soil as a percentage. The drying time is generally 16 hours. ② Compaction Test a. Standard Proctor Test (a) The compaction test is performed using the test method specified in KSF 2312, with the sample being divided into three layers and placed into a 1,000 cc mold. A test is performed to determine the dry density by compacting the sample with a 2.5 kg rammer, dropping it 25 times (drop height of 30 cm), and measuring the weight and moisture content of the compacted sample. (b) The test method involves performing 4 to 7 compaction tests while varying the moisture content of the sample from the dry to the wet side to create a compaction curve (moisture content-dry density curve) and determine the optimum moisture content and maximum dry density. The allowable moisture content is generally within ±5% of the optimum moisture content. B. Rapid Compaction Test (a) To compare the maximum dry density and optimum moisture content measured by the standard compaction test with the in-situ dry density and in-situ moisture content, a minimum of 24 hours is required. However, the rapid compaction test allows for the knowledge of the ratio (%) of the in-situ density to the maximum density in the laboratory before directly measuring the in-situ moisture content at the construction site, and the difference between the in-situ moisture content and the optimum moisture content can be obtained at the same time, thus enabling rapid quality control of the embankment. The test method is as follows. ㉮ Specimen preparation. Samples excavated from in-situ test pits are sieved through a No. 4 sieve and the fraction passing the No. 4 sieve (-No. 4) is used for compaction testing. Since 2 to 4 compaction tests must be performed for one in-situ test, one batch of specimens is... Using 3.5 kg will require approximately 14 kg or more of sample. When adding water to the sample, sprinkle it evenly over the sample surface quickly and mix thoroughly by hand until the moisture is completely dispersed within 5 minutes. When drying the sample, use oven drying or natural drying, stirring frequently to ensure even drying. ㉯ Rapid compaction. Compact the sample that has passed through the 4th sieve at the in-situ moisture content using a specified compaction method, and then measure the moist density of that sample. Sample that has passed through the 4th sieve. Add 70 cc of water (2%) to 3.5 kg, mix well, and compact using the proctor compaction method. The moisture density is then... Calculate the adjusted moist density by dividing by 1.02. At this point, you can obtain the adjusted moist density without calculation by using a chart. The results obtained in this way are used to draw a compaction curve using the parabolic method. ㉰ Quality control test values. The ratio of the in-situ dry density to the maximum dry density obtained in the laboratory, which is the compaction ratio D(%), can be calculated using the following formula. "3.10-1). In field tests, to determine D before knowing the water content, divide the in-place wet density by the wet density corresponding to the peak of the compaction curve." 3.10-2). To determine this C-value before knowing the water content ratio, divide the in-situ wet density by the wet density at 0% moisture content." 3.10-4). The calculated D values, C values, and Wo - Wf values obtained as above are sufficient data for quality control of the embankment, and the following values can be obtained by measuring the in-situ density and the moisture content of the compacted sample. 3.10-5) ( 3.10-6) ( 3.10-7) Optimal Function Ratio = ( 3.10-8)③ Field Density Tester. Methods for measuring the density of embankment fill to control quality include the water replacement method, core cutter method, sand replacement method, and RI method. The sand replacement method is suitable for cohesive soils and granular soils and can be used to measure soils with a maximum particle size of 5 cm or less. The water replacement method using a volumeter is suitable for cohesive soils with low gravel content, as the rubber membrane is likely to rupture when there is a lot of gravel. Caution should be exercised when testing expansive soils, as the volume of the test hole may be underestimated, resulting in a higher density. The core cutter method is unsuitable for soils containing gravel or non-cohesive soils, as the mold does not fit well and the sample is disturbed; it is effective for cohesive soils. The following describes each measurement method. (A) Water Replacement Method (Refer to KSF 2347) (B) This method uses a “volumeter” to measure density, and the instrument consists of a body and a density measuring plate. The density measurement is performed in the following sequence: ㉮ Disassemble the “volumeter” body, fill the cylinder with water, and reassemble it. ㉯ Remove loose soil from the embankment surface, level it, install the density measuring plate, and place the body on top of it. ㉰ Press down on the body to prevent it from floating, open the valve on the body, and press the rubber valve. Repeat the pressing operation to bring the rubber membrane into close contact with the ground surface, so that the water level in the cylinder reaches its lowest point. Then, read the scale (volume) displayed on the cylinder and record it as the initial reading (Rs). ㉱ Remove the rubber valve, reverse it, and operate the rubber valve to remove the air from the cylinder, returning the rubber membrane into the cylinder and lock the valve. ㉲ Remove the body and dig a test hole to the required depth through the hole in the density measuring plate, collect all the excavated soil, and measure the weight (Ws) of the soil and the water content. ㉳ Place the body on the density measuring plate, reverse the rubber valve, and open the valve. ㉴ Hold the body to prevent it from floating, and operate the rubber valve to bring the rubber membrane into the test hole, bringing it into close contact with the water level reaching its lowest point, and record the reading at this time as the final reading (Re). ㉵ Remove the rubber valve, reverse it, and operate the rubber valve to bring the rubber membrane into the cylinder, lock the valve, move to the next measurement location, and repeat this process to measure the density. ㉶ Density calculation is as follows. 3.10-9) Here, V: Volume of test hole (cm³), Re: Initial reading of the Bourdon tube water level (cm³), Rs: Final reading of the Bourdon tube water level (cm³), γt: Moist unit weight of the fill (g/cm³), Ws: Weight of soil excavated from the test hole (g), γd: Dry unit weight of the fill (g/cm³), ω: Water content of the fill (%). (b) Core cutter method (c) This method measures the density using a core cutter, and the measurement sequence is as follows. ㉮ Remove loose soil from the surface of the fill and level it, then place the core cutter and slowly press it into the fill while excavating around the core cutter. Avoid applying impact load during this process; if unavoidable, gently tap with a hammer or club. ㉯ Press the core cutter into the fill to the collar and excavate the outer and bottom surfaces of the core cutter to lift it. Take care not to disturb the core during this process. ㉰ Remove the collar and cutting edge from the core cutter and trim the upper and lower surfaces of the sample straight from the center to the edge of the cylinder to make them flat. ㉱ Measure the weight of the cylinder containing the trimmed sample (Ws+c) and also measure the water content of the sample. (c) Sand substitution method (Refer to KSF 2311) (c) This method is a method for measuring the unit weight of the fill using a sand density tester, and the measurement sequence is as follows. ㉮ Volume verification of the cylinder and connector. Assemble the sand density tester and weigh the weight of the tester. . Set up the tester and open the valve. . Add water to the funnel of the tester until the valve hole overflows. Ensure that no air remains in the connector at this time. . Close the valve, discard the water collected in the funnel, and wipe the outer surface of the tester and the inner surface of the funnel well with a dry cloth. . Weigh the tester filled with water (W2) and measure the water temperature inside the tester. . Repeat the above operation three or more times to obtain the volume of the cylinder and connector (V1). 3.10-10) Here, V1: Volume of the flask including the connection part and valve hole (cm³), W2: Weight when water fills the flask and connection part (g), W1: Total weight of the measuring instrument (g), Υwt: Specific gravity of water at t℃ (g/cm³). ☱ Test for the specific gravity of test sand. Place the thoroughly dried measuring instrument on a level surface and close the valve. After adding test sand to the top of the funnel, open the valve and add sand until it fills the flask and connection part. At this time, the sand in the funnel descends to the bottom, so replenish the sand so that the sand surface is always maintained at 1/2 or more of the height of the funnel. When the movement of the sand stops and it is confirmed that the flask and connection part are filled with sand, close the valve, remove the remaining sand, and weigh the weight (W4) of the measuring instrument filled with sand. Subtract the weight of the measuring instrument itself (W1) from the weight of the measuring instrument filled with sand (W4) to obtain the weight of the sand in the measuring instrument (W5), and calculate the specific gravity of the sand as follows. 3.10-11) Here, Υts: Unit weight of test sand (g/cm³), W4: Weight when sand is filled into the bottle and connected part (g), W1: Weight of the measuring device (g), V1: Volume of the bottle including the connection and valve hole of the density measuring device (cm³). ㉰ Sand weight verification for filling the funnel. After filling the bottle with a sufficient amount of sand to fill the funnel, close the valve and weigh (W6). In the case of verification by the measurement in (s), use W4 of the measurement in (b) as is. Place the measuring device on a level wooden board so that the funnel is closely attached to the board. Open the valve and allow the sand in the bottle to flow into the funnel. When the sand movement stops, close the valve. Remove the sand that has moved into the funnel, weigh the measuring device and the remaining sand (W7), and calculate the sand weight (W8) required to fill the funnel as (W4-W7). Excavate the soil from within the base plate holes using an auger, trowel, or spoon and place it entirely into a container. Weigh the excavated soil from the test hole and the container (Ｗsc), thoroughly mix the soil, and take a sample for moisture content testing to measure the moisture content (Ｗ). Weigh the weight of the measuring device filled with sand (Ｗ4). Calculate the volume of the test hole as follows. 3.10-12) Here, V: Volume of the test mold (cm³), W8: Weight of sand required to fill the funnel (g), W10: Weight of sand in the test mold and funnel (g), W11: Weight of sand required to fill the test mold (g) (라) RI Method ☤ This method measures the moisture content and density of the embankment using radioactive isotopes. Currently used are neutron moisture gauges and γ-ray density gauges, which can be measured directly on-site, without interfering with the construction of the embankment. It is also easy to operate, requires no skill, and has no personal error. However, it requires a radioactive isotope handling license from the Ministry of Science and Technology to use, and special precautions are needed for transportation and storage. A comparison of results measured in the United States using this method with those obtained by conventional methods showed a moisture content of 2 %, and dry density was Although it exhibited an error of 0.08 g/㎤, its fast measurement speed makes it practically sufficient, and the measurement principle will be omitted here. ④ In-situ permeability test. There are various in-situ permeability tests, but for impermeable materials, it can be simply measured using a sand density test well. (a) The test well is formed as a vertical well with a diameter of approximately 10～40 cm (depth >20 cm). (b) Fill the vertical well with clean crushed stone or gravel to a depth of 1/2～2/3 of the well depth, place two pipes (approximately 5 cm in diameter) on top of it, and fill the remaining space with clean gravel. (c) Inject water through pipes connected to a reservoir while maintaining a constant water level, and when the infiltration rate becomes constant, measure the water level inside the vertical well, the water flow rate, and the water injection time using a water level gauge and a flow meter. When measuring the water level through the water level gauge, a float is used; if this is difficult, a wooden board with nails driven in is used so that the nail tips are always in contact with the water surface to maintain a constant water level, and the water depth (H) inside the vertical well is calculated. (d) Calculate the water depth (H) inside the vertical well using the measured water level, and calculate the water flow rate per unit time (Q) by dividing the water flow rate by the water injection time, and calculate the in-situ permeability coefficient using the following formula. 3.10-13) Here, Q: Flow rate per unit time (cm³/s), r: Radius of the vertical borehole, H: Water depth inside the vertical borehole. During in-situ permeability tests, cover the area with a thin plastic sheet, excluding the water level gauge, to prevent evaporation due to direct sunlight or wind. ⑤ Evaluation and Utilization of Test Results. Compare each measurement obtained from the quality control test with the specified limits defined in the specifications, and take measures to rework if insufficient. In addition to these measures, the construction supervisor should focus on eliminating the causes of the insufficient compaction. B. To prevent recurrence, when reviewing the results, identify the range of conditions indicated by the obtained measurements and trace back the process that led to these results. For example, if the water content of the embankment is excessive, manage the borrow area by establishing an excavation plan, including water treatment and rainwater drainage. If the water content of the embankment is within the allowable range, instruct the construction company's geotechnical engineer to increase the voltage and correct the work process. 3.11 Project Management (1) Project management, within the comprehensive management concept of dam construction, involves analyzing the scope of work for each type of construction, establishing process plans that include construction sequence, timing, quantity, and duration. These plans for various work types are then organically integrated and assembled into a comprehensive project plan, which is subsequently implemented to manage the construction process and ensure the completion of the dam within the specified timeframe and quality standards. (2) The construction process for a dam is a complex process involving multiple types of interconnected work. Delays in some work can significantly impact the entire project. Therefore, it is necessary to identify and predict natural phenomena affecting construction, such as weather, river conditions, and water flow changes during the construction period. All elements, including facilities, equipment, materials, personnel, and construction methods, must be closely and organically managed. Furthermore, quality is determined during the construction process and significantly impacts construction costs, necessitating comprehensive management. (3) Project management involves effectively and appropriately combining individual tasks to form individual construction processes. These process plans are then used to rationally manage materials, labor, construction equipment, and budget to efficiently manage the construction process, ensuring the completion of the dam within the specified quality and timeframe. This can be divided into the establishment and management of project plans. 3. 1 1.1 Establishment of Construction Schedule (1) The construction schedule defines the sequence and speed of execution for each individual construction work to complete all construction work for the dam within the specified construction period, and the schedule chart is a graphical representation of this. (2) The schedule chart is broadly divided into a basic schedule chart, which is a schedule chart for each type of work, and a comprehensive schedule chart, which integrates all of these. The comprehensive schedule chart is prepared based on and referencing the basic schedule chart. (3) In establishing the construction plan, first analyze the content of each individual work, then organize the individual tasks sequentially to create a work breakdown structure, illustrating the relationship between individual processes for each type of work to clearly define the flow of work.  Add materials, personnel, and construction equipment to review the standard workload.  Consider holidays, rainy days, preparation time, and other downtime to plan the schedule. (4) Schedule chart formats include horizontal bar charts and graph charts, but in any case, it should allow for comparison of planned and actual progress. Bar graph charts are typically designed with two sections, one for planned progress (represented by a black line) and one for actual progress (represented by a red line). In the comprehensive schedule, the overall progress of each individual work should be indicated by aggregating the progress of each work. It is common to display this using the earned value method, where the work volume of each work is converted into monetary value, but it may also be displayed as a percentage. 3. 1 1.2 Schedule Management (1) Work Volume Management ① This management aims to ensure that planned standard work volumes are executed according to the schedule. This may involve the effective use of methods such as PERT (Program Evaluation and Review Technique) and CPM (Critical Path Method) network analysis. ② Key management items for work volume management include: a. Variations in work volume due to weather changes and other construction disruptions, along with recovery measures; b. Reduction in work efficiency due to machinery and equipment breakdowns and repairs; c. Timely procurement of materials and personnel; d. Other work impediments (e.g., complaints) and reductions in work efficiency, etc. (2) Progress Management ① While it is difficult to uniformly define the timing for measuring completed work to assess construction progress, measurements should be taken at least once a month. The results should be compared with the basic and comprehensive construction plans to identify any discrepancies between planned and actual performance. If the progress falls short of the planned schedule, it should be detected early, and the causes should be analyzed and addressed. ② When there is a significant difference between planned and actual performance and the cause is unavoidable, the schedule should be revised and implemented, potentially through extending working hours, increasing equipment, and increasing personnel. 3.12 Cost Management (1) Cost management involves financial management to effectively and appropriately operate all costs, from minimum unit labor and material costs to other expenses, in order to complete a dam construction project within the specified construction period, ensuring the specified quality with minimal construction costs. It is closely linked to progress management and quality management, and therefore should be managed organically. (2) Construction costs are divided into planned costs and actual costs. Planned costs serve as an operating budget, referring to the design cost or the bid price (winning bid price) in the case of a turnkey project. Actual costs refer to the costs actually incurred during construction. Cost management can be defined as controlling and managing actual costs so that they do not exceed planned costs within a certain period or for each completed milestone, and requires proper management of all costs, from labor, materials, facility, and equipment usage costs required for each work item and task at the minimum unit level, to taxes and other expenses, and should be linked with work management and quality management. (3) Construction cost management distinguishes between planned costs (design costs or bid prices) and actual costs incurred in the actual construction. Cost management involves comparing actual costs with planned costs and managing to ensure that actual costs do not exceed planned costs. It can be considered as taking into account cost aspects in progress management. (4) The classification of construction cost details should be the same as planned costs and actual costs. Direct costs are calculated for each unit work item, such as materials, labor, construction machinery, and other expenses, and indirect costs such as general administrative expenses and taxes are calculated. The sum of these amounts is calculated as the construction cost for each unit work item, and they are aggregated to calculate the total construction cost. (5) It is common for construction cost management to align with the timing of milestone measurement during progress management. This is related to the method of displaying progress in construction management, which converts the progress of the work into monetary value, as milestone measurement itself is a method of cost management. (6) Therefore, cost management should be closely linked and managed organically with quality management and progress management. This is because it requires an appropriate balance between the characteristics of cost management, which aims to minimize costs, and the specificity of quality management, which aims to create the best possible quality. 3.13 Safety Management (1) During the construction period of the dam, safety management is required, including safe construction practices, compliance with relevant laws, regulations, and specifications, and the implementation of necessary measures, plans, training, inspections, and the installation of various safety facilities to prevent accidents. (2) Dam construction involves the use of hazardous materials (explosives, fuel, gas, electricity, etc.), temporary facilities, and the operation of various heavy equipment on uneven terrain, which poses numerous safety risks. Therefore, special attention should be paid to safety management. All relevant regulations must be strictly adhered to, and necessary measures and facilities implemented. A safety management plan should be established, and training and inspections conducted. Contingency plans for unforeseen accidents should also be in place, as well as preparations for natural disasters such as heavy rain, floods, typhoons, and earthquakes. 3. 1 3.1 General Provisions (1) The site manager of a dam construction site shall report to relevant agencies (including permits and licenses) in accordance with applicable laws, specifications, and standards, establish a safety management organization, and develop a safety management plan to implement necessary measures, inspections, and training. (2) Safety signs shall be installed in necessary locations, such as construction site entrances, to raise awareness of warnings and cautions, and if general public access needs to be restricted for safety reasons, designated areas shall be established with "No Entry" signs, fences, barbed wire, and other necessary facilities. (3) At the construction site, construction workers and relevant visitors shall be required to wear safety helmets and other necessary personal protective equipment, and a sufficient quantity of safety helmets and other personal protective equipment shall be prepared for those who enter without preparation. (4) If a safety accident occurs or is likely to occur during construction, immediate and appropriate emergency measures shall be taken, and the situation shall be reported or notified to higher authorities and relevant agencies. (5) The storage, handling, and use of hazardous materials such as explosives, fuel, gas, and electricity shall comply with relevant laws and regulations, and prior instructions from the relevant supervisor shall be obtained before use. (6) Other facilities and measures necessary for safety shall be taken. 3. 1 3.2 Safety Facilities (1) Install various signboards and hazard signs in necessary locations within the construction site. (2) Explosives, fuel, gas, and other hazardous materials shall be stored in storage facilities in accordance with relevant laws and regulations, and access control facilities shall be installed. (3) Install necessary facilities such as railings and fences to restrict access and prevent approach to areas with risks such as falls. (4) Install safety nets in necessary locations. (5) Install other facilities necessary for safety. 3.14 Environmental Management (1) In order to manage the health and hygiene of workers involved in the dam construction project, minimize the environmental impact caused by the construction during the dam construction period, and prevent environmental damage to nearby villagers, related regulations must be complied with, necessary measures and facilities must be implemented, and environmental management must be carried out diligently, including the restoration of damaged environments. (2) During the dam construction period, measures and facilities for the health and hygiene of workers, local residents, and employees in and around the construction site must be installed and maintained. In order to minimize the environmental impact (ecological environment, air, water quality, noise and vibration, waste disposal) caused by the construction, related regulations must be complied with, necessary facilities must be installed, and measures must be taken diligently. 3. 1 To minimize forest removal for the construction of the 4.1 Ecological Environment Management Dam and to ensure the possible migration of fish and other aquatic life as much as possible through temporary drainage facilities such as diversion tunnels for river water diversion, measures will be taken. Furthermore, efforts will be made to protect fish, insects, amphibians, and other creatures inhabiting the river and its vicinity, and to minimize impacts by preserving or minimizing damage to wetlands in the upstream and downstream areas as much as possible. 3. 1 Due to the construction of 4.2 Atmospheric Management Dam, the atmosphere is affected by the blasting of explosives, excavation and relocation of ground, and operation of various heavy equipment. Therefore, in accordance with Article 28 of the Clean Air Conservation Act and Article 62 Paragraph 2 and Appendix 16 of the same Act's Enforcement Regulations, you must report to the city/provincial governor and local environmental management office as a “Floating Dust Business Site” and take measures to prevent the generation of floating dust, including installing facilities. Dust suppression facilities include dust covers, dust nets, dust barriers, dust collectors, and wheel washing facilities, as well as measures such as operating water trucks. 3. 1 To prevent water pollution and minimize impacts caused by construction, such as sediment runoff from excavation and embankment areas during rainfall events under water quality management 4.3, wastewater from batcher plants, generation of turbid suspended solids due to excavation and landfilling, and domestic sewage, necessary facilities including temporary drainage channels, cutoff walls, sedimentation basins, coagulation-flocculation separation treatment facilities, silt barriers, and temporary filter beds shall be installed. 3. 1 To reduce noise and vibration damage to noise and vibration management sites and their vicinity, necessary management measures are implemented, including advance notification of blasting, restriction of heavy equipment operation at night, and so on. 3. 1 We prevent soil and water pollution by processing waste oil, waste materials, other household waste, etc. from waste management equipment and machinery in accordance with relevant laws and regulations.
